It was my idea to watch the game to begin with.

caption: The president of the only group for LGBT students at my college suggested we shouldn’t invite a transwoman to come and speak at our meeting about trans* issues because she had seen her “out of dress” in public and thinks that she “looks like a drag queen and not a real woman.” Even though I’m pangender, she said I shouldn’t speak either because “I"m not really trans.”
quote: The president of the only group for LGBT students at my college suggested we shouldn’t invite a transwoman to come and speak at our meeting about trans* issues because she had seen her “out of dress” in public and thinks that she “looks like a drag queen and not a real woman.” Even though I’m pangender, she said I shouldn’t speak either because “I"m not really trans.”

caption: My grandmother, to me, when I was 15 years old.
quote: “Don’t go getting too independent. Men don’t like that.”
actual_quote: Don’t go getting too independent. Men don’t like that.

caption: I live in a state that has a constitutional prohibition against same sex marriage and see homophobia on a day to day basis. Most of the time, I let it roll off me but there are times when it gets to me like today when I am preparing my taxes and am again reminded that despite almost 18 years together, both the federal and state government still view me as, and force me to check the box that says, “single.” It’s as if my 18 year commitment to my partner, including 15 in which she was active duty military, mean nothing.
quote: I live in a state that has a constitutional prohibition against same sex marriage and see homophobia on a day to day basis. Most of the time, I let it roll off me but there are times when it gets to me like today when I am preparing my taxes and am again reminded that despite almost 18 years together, both the federal and state government still view me as, and force me to check the box that says, “single.” It’s as if my 18 year commitment to my partner, including 15 in which she was active duty military, mean nothing.

caption: Said to me by a sexual health nurse when I was 22 (last year) when I refused contraception. Left me feeling invalidated and later very, very angry.
quote: “It’s just a phase, you’re too young to decide your sexuality, you should just have sex with men till you’re sure.”
actual_quote: It’s just a phase, you’re too young to decide your sexuality, you should just have sex with men till you’re sure.

caption: Last year, an acquaintance of mine gives me a photo of her and her date to formal, with a note on the back saying:
quote:
Last year, an acquaintance of mine gives me a photo of her and her date to formal, with a note on the back saying:
“You’ll always be my sassy gay friend!”
I’m a 15 year old cisgendered male, who doesn’t really fit into many “gay” stereotypes. It made me feel uncomfortable, as though I had to fit into a stereotype because I was gay.

caption: I am a 20 year old Biracial (black and white) female studying Social Work and African American Studies. Today I tried to explain the difference between prejudice and racism to two white women.  They preceded to say that I am a reverse racist, ignorant, and uneducated.
quote:
I am a 20 year old Biracial (black and white) female studying Social Work and African American Studies. Today I tried to explain the difference between prejudice and racism to two white women.  They preceded to say that I am a reverse racist, ignorant, and uneducated.
This makes me feel like no matter how much people of color progress we will never be taken seriously on matters of race by white people.

caption: A fellow woman of color, days before my freshman year of college at a flagship university of Texas. Well, fuck…
quote: “You only got into [my university] because you’re Native American AND Mexican. I had to work harder to get into this same honors program, and that’s not fair.”
actual_quote: You only got into [my university] because you’re Native American AND Mexican. I had to work harder to get into this same honors program, and that’s not fair.

caption: I’m walking out of kroger minding my own business when some old white man walks up to me and says:
quote:
I’m walking out of kroger minding my own business when some old white man walks up to me and says:
You’re black. Where’s the closest ABC store and chicken place?
I stare at him blankly.  This man couldn’t been serious.
Well, where is it lady?
I keep walking.  He shouts again as I walk to my car. As I get into my car, he asks another black person the same question.  I don’t drink and I’m vegan.  Why on earth would I know where a “"chicken place”“ is much less a liquor store?

caption: I am sitting at a gay bar enjoying a drink watching a game and a fellow man of color comes over to me and says: “You must be mixed with something, right?” I couldn’t even speak back to that so I just stared at him begrudged and annoyed that he distracted me from the game for something not worth either of our time. He waited a few seconds to see if I was thinking, but then got the hint and walked away. Is this really…well, never mind.
quote: I am sitting at a gay bar enjoying a drink watching a game and a fellow man of color comes over to me and says: “You must be mixed with something, right?” I couldn’t even speak back to that so I just stared at him begrudged and annoyed that he distracted me from the game for something not worth either of our time. He waited a few seconds to see if I was thinking, but then got the hint and walked away. Is this really…well, never mind.

caption: My boss, talking about one of our sales people, who is very aggressive about closing sales: “You know, she’s from China. It’s 6 billion people fighting over one rice bowl over there.”
quote: My boss, talking about one of our sales people, who is very aggressive about closing sales: “You know, she’s from China. It’s 6 billion people fighting over one rice bowl over there.”
“You mean your boyfriend coded it up in a week!”
actual_quote: You mean your boyfriend coded it up in a week!

quote: “But he can never be a *real* girl.”
actual_quote: But he can never be a *real* girl.

caption: I’m at work, and it’s a busy Sunday morning, where phones are ringing continuously. I have had perhaps 3 hours of really bad sleep, and then had to wake up at 5 AM to be there at 6. Finally, after dealing with several highly irritated customers in a row, I hang up the phone and curse for a second. One coworker looks at me and says: “We need to find you a man and get you laid!” The other just laughs as if it’s the best joke she’s ever heard.
quote: I’m at work, and it’s a busy Sunday morning, where phones are ringing continuously. I have had perhaps 3 hours of really bad sleep, and then had to wake up at 5 AM to be there at 6. Finally, after dealing with several highly irritated customers in a row, I hang up the phone and curse for a second. One coworker looks at me and says: “We need to find you a man and get you laid!” The other just laughs as if it’s the best joke she’s ever heard.

caption: I was sitting with my reportees in a meeting room. I was seated at the head of the table. A male representative from a staffing agency walked in wanting to make a pitch. My reportee asked him to “speak to the boss” (meaning me). The guy looked around and asked “Where is he?”
quote: I was sitting with my reportees in a meeting room. I was seated at the head of the table. A male representative from a staffing agency walked in wanting to make a pitch. My reportee asked him to “speak to the boss” (meaning me). The guy looked around and asked “Where is he?”

caption: My co-worker makes it a point to discuss “ghetto names” whenever I am around. She has referred to me as “Bonquisha” and “Sha-neh-neh.” When I told the office manager, she said that I was being too sensitive and not to take her playfulness seriously. Today the office manager started a conversation about “ghetto names” I had to leave the office I was so mad. I didn’t name myself. I love my name. I’m not ashamed of who I am.
quote: My co-worker makes it a point to discuss “ghetto names” whenever I am around. She has referred to me as “Bonquisha” and “Sha-neh-neh.” When I told the office manager, she said that I was being too sensitive and not to take her playfulness seriously. Today the office manager started a conversation about “ghetto names” I had to leave the office I was so mad. I didn’t name myself. I love my name. I’m not ashamed of who I am.

caption: A lady and I are at a bus stop talking about the ESOL training class we just completed. A man walks up, stands between us, and begins talking to my friend, a white woman, about how all of “them” are taking the jobs of Americans. Each time he says “them” he nods his head in the direction of two El Salvadoran men we both know who are standing across the street. He continues his rants peppered with racial slurs until the bus arrives.
quote:
A lady and I are at a bus stop talking about the ESOL training class we just completed. A man walks up, stands between us, and begins talking to my friend, a white woman, about how all of “them” are taking the jobs of Americans. Each time he says “them” he nods his head in the direction of two El Salvadoran men we both know who are standing across the street. He continues his rants peppered with racial slurs until the bus arrives.
He couldn’t read the sadness in her face or her discomfort. I knew she was thinking about her new husband, a man from Guatemala and how he must feel when confronted by people like that.

caption: My supervisor who is a middle class white woman.
quote: “I don’t go to that Target it’s too ghetto.”
actual_quote: I don’t go to that Target it’s too ghetto.

caption: Before class today, some freshmen were talking about a robbery that had occurred on campus earlier that day. They were saying that they should have known, there was some “shady-ass black guy” on the floor and statistically of course he was going to steal some things. One girl did indeed recognize that this was racist and quite literally checked the room for “people who might get offended.”
quote: Before class today, some freshmen were talking about a robbery that had occurred on campus earlier that day. They were saying that they should have known, there was some “shady-ass black guy” on the floor and statistically of course he was going to steal some things. caption: Told my mother that I wanted to play on my elementary school basketball team and she said yes. My uncle told her that girls who play basketball become lesbians. She quickly changed her mind and told me not to ask her to play basketball every again.
quote: Told my mother that I wanted to play on my elementary school basketball team and she said yes. My uncle told her that girls who play basketball become lesbians. She quickly changed her mind and told me not to ask her to play basketball every again.
“Not all gay men are sissies, but all sissies are gay.”
actual_quote: Not all gay men are sissies, but all sissies are gay.

quote: “My teacher taught us about Africa today. She told us that when she went there, the children didn’t even know what they looked like because mirrors haven’t been invented there. Did you know that the children in Africa don’t even have shoes, or electricity, or running water?”
actual_quote: My teacher taught us about Africa today. She told us that when she went there, the children didn’t even know what they looked like because mirrors haven’t been invented there. Did you know that the children in Africa don’t even have shoes, or electricity, or running water?

caption: I started filling out an online survey. I ticked the “female” box when they asked for my gender, but then it started assuming that I read women’s websites/magazines and asking me questions like, “What do you look for when reading women’s magazines” without allowing me to tick a box saying that I don’t read those. I closed the page.
quote: I started filling out an online survey. I ticked the “female” box when they asked for my gender, but then it started assuming that I read women’s websites/magazines and asking me questions like, “What do you look for when reading women’s magazines” without allowing me to tick a box saying that I don’t read those. I closed the page.

caption: A coworker tells me she’s surprised that I came into work today because of the multibillion dollar mall that opened in Salt Lake City. Because I’m gay I must only care about clothes and materialism.
quote: A coworker tells me she’s surprised that I came into work today because of the multibillion dollar mall that opened in Salt Lake City. Because I’m gay I must only care about clothes and materialism.

caption: When I told my family I plan to spend the rest of my life with my girlfriend they laughed as if I was joking…. 4 years later they keep telling us that we “need to find boyfriends” and always refer to her as my “friend” or “flatmate.“
quote: When I told my family I plan to spend the rest of my life with my girlfriend they laughed as if I was joking…. 4 years later they keep telling us that we “need to find boyfriends” and always refer to her as my “friend” or “flatmate.“

caption: I do tech for a play at my school. I am also the only female tech working on the show. One of my duties is to help take out the set pieces at the beginning of rehearsal and put them back at the end. Every time, without fail, there is at least one man (often an actor) who says “that’s too much for a girl to be carrying!” and offers to help me.
quote: I do tech for a play at my school. I am also the only female tech working on the show. caption: My brother works out at a gym and told me about the new workout machines. One machine requires him to exert effort to close his legs. This is called the “good girl.” The other machine requires him to push his legs open. This is called the “bad girl.”
quote: My brother works out at a gym and told me about the new workout machines. One machine requires him to exert effort to close his legs. This is called the “good girl.” The other machine requires him to push his legs open. This is called the “bad girl.”
“I feel so cosmopolitan now, I know a lesbian!”
actual_quote: I feel so cosmopolitan now, I know a lesbian!

quote: “I really wouldn’t worry about being gay. To meet you, no-one would ever guess.”
actual_quote: I really wouldn’t worry about being gay. To meet you, no-one would ever guess.

caption: Whenever I eat a meal served by my aunt or grandmother, I am consistently served less food ( e.g. one less piece of meat or half the serve of vegetables) than the men at the table. Somehow they think because I am female, I am less hungry or am unable to consume as much food.
quote: Whenever I eat a meal served by my aunt or grandmother, I am consistently served less food ( e.g. one less piece of meat or half the serve of vegetables) than the men at the table. Somehow they think because I am female, I am less hungry or am unable to consume as much food.

caption: I am in a pharmacy and need something for sports injury. When I tell the assistant that she laughs and so does her colleague. I am 59 years of age and female.
quote: I am in a pharmacy and need something for sports injury. When I tell the assistant that she laughs and so does her colleague. I am 59 years of age and female.

caption: My professor said, “People are better with race issues and religious issues than they were before."  But he continued to say that Muslims and the issues they cause, contradicting her previous statement.  Little did she know I was a Muslim American sitting the front row of her class in women studies.
quote: My professor said, “People are better with race issues and religious issues than they were before."  But he continued to say that Muslims and the issues they cause, contradicting her previous statement.  Little did she know I was a Muslim American sitting the front row of her class in women studies.

caption: If you’re in the United States, do this: consult your local newspaper for a comprehensive listing of all movies that are playing within 50 miles of of your city. Then go to http://www.captionfish.com and do a search for your city. If you are deaf or hard of hearing, then only the titles, show times, and locations listed at CaptionFish are accessible to you. All the rest of the showings in your city are not, because they have no captions available, which means you won’t understand anything that is said in the movie. (Bear in mind that a given movie can have captions “available” and still be inaccessible at a particular location or showing time if the theater does not actually display the captions or have the technology to do this.)
quote: If you’re in the United States, do this: consult your local newspaper for a comprehensive listing of all movies that are playing within 50 miles of of your city. Then go to http://www.captionfish.com and do a search for your city. If you are deaf or hard of hearing, then only the titles, show times, and locations listed at CaptionFish are accessible to you. All the rest of the showings in your city are not, because they have no captions available, which means you won’t understand anything that is said in the movie. (Bear in mind that a given movie can have captions “available” and still be inaccessible at a particular location or showing time if the theater does not actually display the captions or have the technology to do this.)

caption: I pick up the DVD or Blueray and check to see if it has subtitles for deaf people. I find that the main feature does have subtitles, but there is a notation indicating that the special features “may not” have them. As a deaf person, this means I will be able to watch the main feature but cannot count on being able to watch any of the special features.

caption: First day of college and the class (of 15 full time students) also hosts a few over seas students from China. Right before commencement of class I ask my teacher a few questions in my perfect Aussie accent. Teacher walks around class asking each overseas student if they need help understanding English. Teacher approaches me last and asks me if I need help understanding English.

caption: The Dean of students during the current events section of the all-student community meeting explains the Trayvon Martin case.
quote: “Well he was wearing a hoodie… at night… in a gated community.”
actual_quote: Well he was wearing a hoodie… at night… in a gated community.

caption: A blog post about disability microaggressions in an airport.
quote: "Some body needs to attend the luggage"

caption: Trader joe’s soy milk carton, 2013“Soybeans have been cultivated in the Orient for thousands of years. Only recently has the western world embraced this wonderful food source that is both economical and versatile.”
My chemistry teacher was in shock when I got a 103% on an exam; however, she wasn’t shocked when two white kids did well. This was kind of hurtful, but after that the teacher never doubted me.
quote: My chemistry teacher was in shock when I got a 103% on an exam; however, she wasn’t shocked when two white kids did well. This was kind of hurtful, but after that the teacher never doubted me.

caption: My white male professor never made eye contact with students of color during the entire semester. I am Latina.
quote: My white male professor never made eye contact with students of color during the entire semester. I am Latina.
“We have a sexual harassment policy in this class. I know sometimes girls like to flirt with the boys, but I’m asking you to keep that outside the classroom, we’re here to work.”
actual_quote: We have a sexual harassment policy in this class. I know sometimes girls like to flirt with the boys, but I’m asking you to keep that outside the classroom, we’re here to work.

quote: “He’s hot for an Asian.”
actual_quote: He’s hot for an Asian.

caption: One day, I am reading yet another Bobbsey Twin book when suddenly I discover that this book has a character just like me–a little deaf girl. I am joyed: I have never before read a story with a deaf character in it, someone I could identify with. Excitedly I read on. The little deaf girl has trouble understanding most of what Flo and Flo’s mother say to her. Eventually the mother says, “I’ll fix you up,” the girl says, “I’m already mixed up!” And mother and Flo laugh.
quote: One day, I am reading yet another Bobbsey Twin book when suddenly I discover that this book has a character just like me–a little deaf girl. I am joyed: I have never before read a story with a deaf character in it, someone I could identify with. Excitedly I read on. The little deaf girl has trouble understanding most of what Flo and Flo’s mother say to her. Eventually the mother says, “I’ll fix you up,” the girl says, “I’m already mixed up!” And mother and Flo laugh.

caption: A Native American girl keeps her hair waist-length, like other girls on her reservation. One day a teacher tells her that this “too Indian” and forces a severe haircut on her. She shares this story perhaps 7-10+ years later with me and other classmates in a graduate classroom. Her hair is still short, only a little past her ear. Someone in the class asks why she doesn’t allow it to grow again now that she is adult and has that choice. She says, it would hurt too much.
quote: A Native American girl keeps her hair waist-length, like other girls on her reservation. One day a teacher tells her that this “too Indian” and forces a severe haircut on her. She shares this story perhaps 7-10+ years later with me and other classmates in a graduate classroom. Her hair is still short, only a little past her ear. Someone in the class asks why she doesn’t allow it to grow again now that she is adult and has that choice. She says, it would hurt too much.
“You can never be clean: your brown skin won’t wash off.”
actual_quote: You can never be clean: your brown skin won’t wash off.

caption: I am one of two people of color in my English discussion class at UC Berkeley. I am also a low-income student. The white middle class female a couple of seats away, said the following as one of her friends approached her “Hey Gurrrlll! What’s up! Omg! I’m so ghetto today.” In addition to snapping her fingers and shaking her head. I sat there frozen and powerless. I’m really angry at myself for not speaking up.
quote: I am one of two people of color in my English discussion class at UC Berkeley. I am also a low-income student. The white middle class female a couple of seats away, said the following as one of her friends approached her “Hey Gurrrlll! What’s up! Omg! I’m so ghetto today.” In addition to snapping her fingers and shaking her head. I sat there frozen and powerless. I’m really angry at myself for not speaking up.
“Find yourself an Asian girl. She’ll be more docile.”
actual_quote: Find yourself an Asian girl. She’ll be more docile.

caption: I know a lot of girls who feel they can prove that through their love of whiskey, football, and other stereotypically male things that they are more worthy of friendship and approval by male peers. They feel and act superior to “girly girls” like myself because they don’t buy in to femininity, wear makeup, or eat ice cream when they’re sad, etc. I feel as if they’re declaring that being a woman is a bad thing, and feminine women should be ashamed for acting as such.
quote: I know a lot of girls who feel they can prove that through their love of whiskey, football, and other stereotypically male things that they are more worthy of friendship and approval by male peers. They feel and act superior to “girly girls” like myself because they don’t buy in to femininity, wear makeup, or eat ice cream when they’re sad, etc. I feel as if they’re declaring that being a woman is a bad thing, and feminine women should be ashamed for acting as such.

caption: A friend said this in class, as part of a wider discussion among the others about how some people deliberately try to inspire pity so they can manipulate you. Said while looking straight at me, when she knows that I have abusive parents. Made me feel like I was a horrible person, not to mention betrayed.
quote: “It’s a shame that some people like to use their childhoods to get themselves out of responsibility.”
actual_quote: It’s a shame that some people like to use their childhoods to get themselves out of responsibility.

caption: Two of my friends, one of whom is rather well-off financially, keep referring to expensive things as “classy” and “legitimate”, as if buying the store brand of salt or eating at waffle house makes me less of a person than them. We are all college students, they are both considerably wealthier than I am. Made me feel like I am not regarded as a full person because I am not rich and can’t afford the luxuries that they can.
quote: Two of my friends, one of whom is rather well-off financially, keep referring to expensive things as “classy” and “legitimate”, as if buying the store brand of salt or eating at waffle house makes me less of a person than them. We are all college students, they are both considerably wealthier than I am. Made me feel like I am not regarded as a full person because I am not rich and can’t afford the luxuries that they can.

caption: Facebook reply to someone criticizing Newt Gingrich saying Spanish is the “language of the ghetto." Made me confused. Really exasperated. Surprised that an intelligent kid could be so ignorant.
quote: “I personally don’t feel that I should have to press 3 for English when I try to call the DMV or something, and it is more practical to learn multiple languages if you’re bordered by several countries who all speak different languages. We are not. I’m not advocating a ban or restriction on the use of other languages, but English should take precedence in public education and it would also be good to require a basic understanding of the language before granting full citizenship rights to legal immigrants, to help them become effective and productive members of American society.”
actual_quote: I personally don’t feel that I should have to press 3 for English when I try to call the DMV or something, and it is more practical to learn multiple languages if you’re bordered by several countries who all speak different languages. We are not. I’m not advocating a ban or restriction on the use of other languages, but English should take precedence in public education and it would also be good to require a basic understanding of the language before granting full citizenship rights to legal immigrants, to help them become effective and productive members of American society.

caption: For all four years on the high school dance team, my teammates affectionately called me “Asian” because I was the only Chinese girl on the team. Looking back, that was not a symbol of affection. I should’ve never allowed anyone to believe that my race was the only important thing about me.
quote: For all four years on the high school dance team, my teammates affectionately called me “Asian” because I was the only Chinese girl on the team. Looking back, that was not a symbol of affection. I should’ve never allowed anyone to believe that my race was the only important thing about me.

caption: A fun message sent to our blog:
quote:
A fun message sent to our blog:
“You should call this the "Take Offense at Anything” blog. Point being: others cannot make you feel, that’s completely up to you.“
Yuuppp, microaggression! thanks.

caption: We wouldn’t allow the only black girl in our class to play with us /because she was black/. My classmates and I, in our predominantly Latino kindergarten. Late 1990s. Looking back on it now, it makes me sad that, even at that age, we knew to treat other POC poorly.
quote: We wouldn’t allow the only black girl in our class to play with us /because she was black/. My classmates and I, in our predominantly Latino kindergarten. Late 1990s. Looking back on it now, it makes me sad that, even at that age, we knew to treat other POC poorly.

caption: My university is huge on men’s hockey. Tonight an important women’s hockey game is going on, and someone puts up a sign that reads “Girl’s hockey game tonight, make the time to go.” Women’s hockey isn’t a fraction as big as men’s hockey and the sign is meant to promote the team and get people to go to that game, but I can’t help thinking how ironic the sign is. Nobody would ever call men’s hockey “boy’s” hockey. It’s like not even a supporter is taking women’s hockey seriously by calling it girl’s hockey.
quote: My university is huge on men’s hockey. Tonight an important women’s hockey game is going on, and someone puts up a sign that reads “Girl’s hockey game tonight, make the time to go.” Women’s hockey isn’t a fraction as big as men’s hockey and the sign is meant to promote the team and get people to go to that game, but I can’t help thinking how ironic the sign is. Nobody would ever call men’s hockey “boy’s” hockey. It’s like not even a supporter is taking women’s hockey seriously by calling it girl’s hockey.

caption: At a colloquium in a US physics graduate school, a white professor notices a coffee spill near where four of us South Asians were seated, looks at us and jokes, “Is that the work of terrorists?”
quote: At a colloquium in a US physics graduate school, a white professor notices a coffee spill near where four of us South Asians were seated, looks at us and jokes, “Is that the work of terrorists?”

caption: My coworker (and friend) on the subject of LGBT youth, bullying, and suicide, during a discussion of the recent Rolling Stone article on the subject. I’m still angry, four hours later. I also feel exceptionally betrayed, because she knows I’m queer.
quote: “They need to learn how suck it up and take it.”
actual_quote: They need to learn how suck it up and take it.

caption: On Australia Day, during a heated conversation over the current state of this country I was told my ‘left wing’ views deemed un-Australian. One tells me if I hate this country so much why don’t I leave.
quote:
On Australia Day, during a heated conversation over the current state of this country I was told my ‘left wing’ views deemed un-Australian. One tells me if I hate this country so much why don’t I leave.
I am an Aboriginal man with white skin. This is my country. Where can I go? How can I be un-Australian?
“People are so bipolar these days.”
actual_quote: People are so bipolar these days.

caption: On several social occassions, I’ve been told that I’m “pretty cool and articulate for an Indian guy.”
quote:
On several social occassions, I’ve been told that I’m “pretty cool and articulate for an Indian guy.”
I’m a 27 year-old South Asian male who has lived in Australia for 5 years now.

caption: My grandmother, while we were going through my recently deceased grandfather’s possessions. I was interested in the tool collection, since I am a SET BUILDER, but my grandmother wanted my younger brother to have them, since he is a boy.
quote: “No, you’re a girl, you don’t need them. We’ll save these tools for your brother.”
actual_quote: No, you’re a girl, you don’t need them. We’ll save these tools for your brother.

caption: I receive a letter at work addressed to “Gentlemen,” rather than “To Whom This May Concern.” I am a woman in a male-dominated field, though it is growing less-so.
quote: I receive a letter at work addressed to “Gentlemen,” rather than “To Whom This May Concern.” I am a woman in a male-dominated field, though it is growing less-so.

caption: My husband and I were moving into a new apartment, and both carrying things into the house from our truck.  While my husband was inside, I was outside carrying an armful of boxes and the male neighbors across the street called across to me:  "You’re doing too much.  Where’s your boyfriend?“  I told them he was inside, and that I was fine.  My husband later told me that when he went outside to grab more boxes, they called him a "lazy motherfucker” and told him he shouldn’t be “making me” lift things.  I am a slim woman of average height, but at that time I worked in a warehouse and was more than able to lift heavy items.
quote: My husband and I were moving into a new apartment, and both carrying things into the house from our truck.  While my husband was inside, I was outside carrying an armful of boxes and the male neighbors across the street called across to me:  "You’re doing too much.  Where’s your boyfriend?“  I told them he was inside, and that I was fine.  My husband later told me that when he went outside to grab more boxes, they called him a "lazy motherfucker” and told him he shouldn’t be “making me” lift things.  I am a slim woman of average height, but at that time I worked in a warehouse and was more than able to lift heavy items.

caption: I am in a meeting with my boss and my white co-worker and he directs his attention to her and says  "you are doing and awesome job,  you are a quick study, and you can work independently, plus your are a great role model.“  But no way whatsoever did he direct any positive comments to me nor really look my way, the Mexican employee. In fact I have to ask a question in order for him to even look at me. What sucks is that I work at a remote University where we are suppose to be sensitive and have awareness for this behavior.
quote: I am in a meeting with my boss and my white co-worker and he directs his attention to her and says  "you are doing and awesome job,  you are a quick study, and you can work independently, plus your are a great role model.“  But no way whatsoever did he direct any positive comments to me nor really look my way, the Mexican employee. In fact I have to ask a question in order for him to even look at me. What sucks is that I work at a remote University where we are suppose to be sensitive and have awareness for this behavior.

caption: I have to walk to catch the bus so I can attend my college classes Monday - Thursday. Men passing by me in cars openly stare at me (craning there heads around to keep me within eyesight as they pass), they honk at me, and I am often offered rides by older men. It makes me feel uncomfortable. Why can’t a 20 year old woman walk down the street without being objectified?
quote: I have to walk to catch the bus so I can attend my college classes Monday - Thursday. Men passing by me in cars openly stare at me (craning there heads around to keep me within eyesight as they pass), they honk at me, and I am often offered rides by older men. It makes me feel uncomfortable. Why can’t a 20 year old woman walk down the street without being objectified?

caption: I wish I was comfortable enough to walk out of my house without some sort of jacket or other shapeless covering to hide my body from leery stares. Makes me feel objectified, ashamed, uncomfortable, inhibited.
quote: I wish I was comfortable enough to walk out of my house without some sort of jacket or other shapeless covering to hide my body from leery stares. Makes me feel objectified, ashamed, uncomfortable, inhibited.

caption: A white woman ran out of her office to stop me in the hallway when I was going to the library of a different department to print an article. I had been working for over 3 years in that natural history musem a graduate student researcher. Because most African American employees were support staff and I was unfamiliar to her, the woman just assumed that I was a suspicious visitor. At first, I felt confused and uncomfortable. Later, I felt angry and hurt. It was as though the woman was saying that I did not belong.
quote: “Excuse me. Are you lost?”
actual_quote: Excuse me. Are you lost?

caption: My boss, to me. I’m Shawnee.
quote: “I’ve never even met a native American!”
actual_quote: I’ve never even met a native American!

caption: I teach at an elementary school. While in a staff meeting, it is brought up that a student in a nearby school has come out as gay. He is being bullied and harassed profusely. The school board treats dealing with this like a huge inconvenience.  It was also brought up that his father is gay. A staff member in the room says, “well, I guess he can’t be that gay if he has kids.” Everyone in the room laughs.
quote: I teach at an elementary school. While in a staff meeting, it is brought up that a student in a nearby school has come out as gay. He is being bullied and harassed profusely. The school board treats dealing with this like a huge inconvenience.  It was also brought up that his father is gay. A staff member in the room says, “well, I guess he can’t be that gay if he has kids.” Everyone in the room laughs.

caption: When my mother said this, I knew coming out to her as a feminine lesbian was not going to go well. I was right. She told me she was confused because I wear dresses.
quote: “Apparently [the actress who plays] Garcia [on Criminal Minds] is a lesbian… What a shame. She’s such a cute girl. I really wouldn’t have expected it.”
actual_quote: Apparently [the actress who plays] Garcia [on Criminal Minds] is a lesbian… What a shame. She’s such a cute girl. I really wouldn’t have expected it.

caption: I’m walking down the street in a neighborhood in DC. A truck stops and lets me cross to the sidewalk. After I pass the truck the driver sticks his head out the window and yells “Smile for me honey! The least you can do is smile!”  Made me feel objectified, powerless, like he could tell me how to act.
quote: I’m walking down the street in a neighborhood in DC. A truck stops and lets me cross to the sidewalk. After I pass the truck the driver sticks his head out the window and yells “Smile for me honey! The least you can do is smile!”  Made me feel objectified, powerless, like he could tell me how to act.

caption: My mother to me, after I disclosed to her that I had been raped a few days prior. I was 11. I eventually told her I made the whole thing up to stop her from saying things like this. She still thinks I made it up. I’m 20 now.
quote: “I had a feeling I would need to watch you for promiscuity.”
actual_quote: I had a feeling I would need to watch you for promiscuity.

caption: One of my close guy friends used to joke about how I broke the elevator in his building; he defended himself by saying that because he didn’t think I was fat, it was okay. He doesn’t know that I’ve been struggling with bulimia for nearly a year.
quote: One of my close guy friends used to joke about how I broke the elevator in his building; he defended himself by saying that because he didn’t think I was fat, it was okay. He doesn’t know that I’ve been struggling with bulimia for nearly a year.

caption: A man in my class, to a woman he had interrupted six or seven times.
quote: “Don’t interrupt me.”
actual_quote: Don’t interrupt me.

caption: I recently joined a Kung Fu student club.  Around 5pm, the buildings become open to students only, and you must present a valid ID to gain access. I am African American. Around 5pm, I am walking to practice with three friends: two ethnically Chinese and the latter Cambodian.  We reach the front desk, and the student worker only asks to see my student ID.  My friends are allowed access, no questions asked.   I don’t know if it was race alone, or race and gender.  I am trans.  People seem to be more cautious the more masculine I become.
quote: I recently joined a Kung Fu student club.  Around 5pm, the buildings become open to students only, and you must present a valid ID to gain access. I am African American. Around 5pm, I am walking to practice with three friends: two ethnically Chinese and the latter Cambodian.  We reach the front desk, and the student worker only asks to see my student ID.  My friends are allowed access, no questions asked.   I don’t know if it was race alone, or race and gender.  I am trans.  People seem to be more cautious the more masculine I become.

caption: “I am a female going into my third year of engineering. In a field where arrogance and chauvinism is legendary. If everyone is working on a problem, guys go to guys first to get things explained, they would never come ask me. One time in class a guy came up to me to try and explain the problem. When I told him I had already done it, he patted me on the back and said, "good for youu!” Like he was talking to a puppy.
quote:
“I am a female going into my third year of engineering. In a field where arrogance and chauvinism is legendary. If everyone is working on a problem, guys go to guys first to get things explained, they would never come ask me. One time in class a guy came up to me to try and explain the problem. When I told him I had already done it, he patted me on the back and said, "good for youu!” Like he was talking to a puppy.
Even professors have this view. I was involved in a group project with another guy and during a class brainstorm the professor approached the male and asked him his thoughts. He didn’t even acknowledge me, and then moved on to the next group. “

caption: I’m working hard for my degree in Computer Engineering, the passion of my life, and my dream is to get a Ph.D and become a researcher. My father once told me I should really think about becoming a teacher for elementary or high school because it’s a good job for a woman who has to take care of her family.
quote: I’m working hard for my degree in Computer Engineering, the passion of my life, and my dream is to get a Ph.D and become a researcher. My father once told me I should really think about becoming a teacher for elementary or high school because it’s a good job for a woman who has to take care of her family.

caption: Customer, after I told him my name. I am an Asian American woman. I felt extremely irritated.
quote: “That’s not your real name. You’re supposed to have a foreign name or something.”
actual_quote: That’s not your real name. You’re supposed to have a foreign name or something.

caption: I am tabling at the Black Monologues, an event put on by my office, Multicultural Involvement & Community Advocacy. My job is to answer questions and get people to sign up for the list serv. One man is about to sign up but then sees that we serve bisexual students. He points to the word bisexual on our placard and says, “I cannot sign with you because this is unnatural,” and then promptly walks away. As a worker I am obligated to smile and say, “Enjoy the show, anyways!”
quote: I am tabling at the Black Monologues, an event put on by my office, Multicultural Involvement & Community Advocacy. My job is to answer questions and get people to sign up for the list serv. One man is about to sign up but then sees that we serve bisexual students. He points to the word bisexual on our placard and says, “I cannot sign with you because this is unnatural,” and then promptly walks away. As a worker I am obligated to smile and say, “Enjoy the show, anyways!”

caption: Whilst complaining about the negative portrayals of women by the media to my friends, my male friend angrily snapped at me “then just stop watching movies and tv shows, no one is forcing you.” My other two friends with us, who are girls, just stayed silent.
quote: Whilst complaining about the negative portrayals of women by the media to my friends, my male friend angrily snapped at me “then just stop watching movies and tv shows, no one is forcing you.” My other two friends with us, who are girls, just stayed silent.

caption: I am sitting in a study area, working on a paper. A white guy comes in, his eyes glued to me. Initially he reaches for a seat facing me, but stops, looks at me fearfully once again, and decides to sit on the other side.
quote: I am sitting in a study area, working on a paper. A white guy comes in, his eyes glued to me. Initially he reaches for a seat facing me, but stops, looks at me fearfully once again, and decides to sit on the other side.

caption: An attorney at the law firm I work for. All the secretaries are adults, most of us are older than him. But we’re always “the girls.”
quote: “I’ll ask one of the girls to do it.”
actual_quote: I’ll ask one of the girls to do it.

caption: Random 5 year old to me and my boyfriend in Disneyland. Made me feel objectified.
quote: “Hello! Hi! Hello! Chinese! Chinese!”
actual_quote: Hello! Hi! Hello! Chinese! Chinese!

quote: “That lipstick looks so great on you. Usually when black girls use red lipstick it comes out really trashy, but you make it work.”
actual_quote: That lipstick looks so great on you. Usually when black girls use red lipstick it comes out really trashy, but you make it work.

caption: “I’m sitting at a noisy pub with a male friend. We lean in close to each other to be heard over the music. Occasionally, he puts his hand on my lower back when he speaks. Occasionally becomes always; lower back becomes upper butt. I tell him it bothers me that he puts his hand on my ass every time he talks to me.
quote:
“I’m sitting at a noisy pub with a male friend. We lean in close to each other to be heard over the music. Occasionally, he puts his hand on my lower back when he speaks. Occasionally becomes always; lower back becomes upper butt. I tell him it bothers me that he puts his hand on my ass every time he talks to me.
"But I don’t mean anything by it!” he responds, with a hurt look in his eyes. He made me feel like I have no say in what matters to ME regarding who touches my body where.

caption: I have albinism. It is screamed at me on the street. Dozens of times over my life. Made me feel like a freak. Like I was about to get beat down if I speak up. Sometimes I speak up.
quote: “Get a suntan!”
actual_quote: Get a suntan!

caption: A white person when I told them that their use of an “Indian” accent was racist.
quote: “It wasn’t racist against Indians. I’m Indian. I was born in India.”
actual_quote: It wasn’t racist against Indians. I’m Indian. I was born in India.

caption: Just went to see my doctor about an “intimate issue.” He made a joke about sex with my girlfriend. I have a boyfriend. I’m fine with calling my significant other my boyfriend or girlfriend, but I’d think a doctor should be neutral, right?
quote: Just went to see my doctor about an “intimate issue.” He made a joke about sex with my girlfriend. I have a boyfriend. I’m fine with calling my significant other my boyfriend or girlfriend, but I’d think a doctor should be neutral, right?

caption: laughingsquid:SNL Imagines Talking Starbucks Verismo Coffee Makers That Provide the Complete Starbucks Experience at HomeThis was pretty racist. Makes one wonder how white the SNL writer’s room is.(via laughingsquid)

My team manager at my firm said to me and my female coworker. Telling us that we weren’t one of “"those girls”“ was in someway supposed to make it OK.  When my coworker and I politely called him out on his remarks, telling him they were sexist and hurtful, he spent half an hour telling us how most girls he had met were "dumb” and “irrational/incapable of logic,” and offered to send us research papers and articles that back up his claims.  My male teammates told me I shouldn’t let such thing upset me, that I was making too big a deal out of it, and that my team leader was entitled to his opinion. Made me feel hurt, betrayed, angry, shocked that even though I work at a leading consulting firm that prides itself on equal oportunitu hiring and gender equaility, I was advised to “let the issue go, and not make such a big deal out of it.”
quote: “I think girls are dumb and incapable of logical reasoning. Current company excluded, of course.”
actual_quote: I think girls are dumb and incapable of logical reasoning. Current company excluded, of course.

caption: The Queer Resource Center at my college calls a meeting of the LGBTQ group leaders to discuss a new initiative. Over the course of the discussion, leaders of the mainstream organizations say that LGBTQ issues should be treated as on par with race, gender and socioeconomic status. As a poor, queer woman of color, I have experienced first-hand how all of these identities are subject to erasure on my campus, particularly in spaces in which I’m pushed to choose between my race and sexuality. As the leader of a group serving queer students of color, I’m aggravated at their backhanded suggestions that my group disrupts the “united front” of the queer community when they so actively shut me down and out.
quote: The Queer Resource Center at my college calls a meeting of the LGBTQ group leaders to discuss a new initiative. Over the course of the discussion, leaders of the mainstream organizations say that LGBTQ issues should be treated as on par with race, gender and socioeconomic status. As a poor, queer woman of color, I have experienced first-hand how all of these identities are subject to erasure on my campus, particularly in spaces in which I’m pushed to choose between my race and sexuality. As the leader of a group serving queer students of color, I’m aggravated at their backhanded suggestions that my group disrupts the “united front” of the queer community when they so actively shut me down and out.

caption: My friend’s mom, about me and two other girls (I’m Asian so are they) but does not say that about the other white girl in our group (she did not pay for the trip). The sad part is that me and the two Asian girls over paid so the trip can even happen.
quote: “How are your friends paying you back for the trip? Are they paying you back with their financial aid money? That’s just tax money going back to us!”
actual_quote: How are your friends paying you back for the trip? Are they paying you back with their financial aid money? That’s just tax money going back to us!

caption: Today, a building inspector at my job described me as a “beautiful little girl.” I’m 27 years old.  Made me feel trivial, powerless, infantilized.
quote: Today, a building inspector at my job described me as a “beautiful little girl.” I’m 27 years old.  Made me feel trivial, powerless, infantilized.

caption: My friends deface a school advertisement for the National Association of Mental Illness, changing it from ‘You are not crazy’ to 'You are crazy.’ I want to tell them about my anxiety disorder but I keep my mouth shut and try to laugh with them instead.  Made me feel like they would treat me differently if they knew about my mental illness.
quote: My friends deface a school advertisement for the National Association of Mental Illness, changing it from ‘You are not crazy’ to 'You are crazy.’ I want to tell them about my anxiety disorder but I keep my mouth shut and try to laugh with them instead.  Made me feel like they would treat me differently if they knew about my mental illness.

caption: Friend’s Facebook status.
quote: “There are scholarships available solely for black men, black women, only women, Hispanic men and women…but if there was a scholarship that only a white man could apply for, I bet it would cause an uproar. Just sayin’. Is this fair in today’s day and age? What did my generation do to oppress any specific group of people? Isn’t it time for equality across the board?”
actual_quote: There are scholarships available solely for black men, black women, only women, Hispanic men and women…but if there was a scholarship that only a white man could apply for, I bet it would cause an uproar. Just sayin’. Is this fair in today’s day and age? What did my generation do to oppress any specific group of people? Isn’t it time for equality across the board?

caption: Said by a classmate about an author who was invited to our English lecture who was raised in an extremely poor family. Made me feel angry, that my fellow students felt it was okay to judge her whole personality and the meaning of her literary works based solely on her social class.
quote: “She’s not a real writer - she’s a crackhead and a half!”
actual_quote: She’s not a real writer - she’s a crackhead and a half!

caption: I find it bewildering when people tell me “Wow! you’re English is really good!” just because I am Asian. I usually respond by calmly saying “Thank you” and “You’re English isn’t bad either” which always gets a good reaction!
quote: I find it bewildering when people tell me “Wow! you’re English is really good!” just because I am Asian. I usually respond by calmly saying “Thank you” and “You’re English isn’t bad either” which always gets a good reaction!

caption: I am a 20 year old male and I swish, I flame and I sparkle. People in my city are almost never threatening to me, but people constantly need to let me know they disapprove of my presentation.
quote:
I am a 20 year old male and I swish, I flame and I sparkle. People in my city are almost never threatening to me, but people constantly need to let me know they disapprove of my presentation.
I was walking down the street past a group of men leaving a Mexican restaurant. One of them turned around, faced me and said “What the fuck, did you lose a bet? Only in Portland…” His friends all laughed.
Last week I was waiting for a bus with an older woman who was talking on her cell phone. “The world sure has changed,” she said slowly, then looking at me, and when she made eye contact, she continued, Faggots everywhere.” Made me feel tired.

caption: Yesterday, my T.A. said the n-word in class. Students laughed. I cried.
quote: Yesterday, my T.A. said the n-word in class. Students laughed. I cried.

caption: In work I was struggling to carry something heavy. My boss sees this and asks why I didn’t ask him for help, I said it was because I didn’t want to be perceived as weak, his response “you’re a woman! that’s expected!”
quote: In work I was struggling to carry something heavy. My boss sees this and asks why I didn’t ask him for help, I said it was because I didn’t want to be perceived as weak, his response “you’re a woman! that’s expected!”

caption: I play viola in a rock band at a local bar. After finishing a set, I was talking to a fan who marvelled at how “ironic” my name was (it’s an English name) because I look like such a “gangsta thug”. Apparently t-shirt + designer jeans + viola = gangsta thug. Oh right. And black skin. Made me feel irritated, frustrated.
quote: I play viola in a rock band at a local bar. After finishing a set, I was talking to a fan who marvelled at how “ironic” my name was (it’s an English name) because I look like such a “gangsta thug”. Apparently t-shirt + designer jeans + viola = gangsta thug. Oh right. And black skin. Made me feel irritated, frustrated.

caption: I was called by the name of my classmate everyday for 10 consecutive months during two creative writing courses in undergrad. Everyone said we were pretty much interchangeable (we were both black females and the only black people in the class) so why did it matter if they didn’t get my name right and called my someone else’s? The professor was the person to start this name mix up trend and thought it was funny to call us interchangeable. Made me feel angry, generalized, hurt, disrespected.
quote: I was called by the name of my classmate everyday for 10 consecutive months during two creative writing courses in undergrad. Everyone said we were pretty much interchangeable (we were both black females and the only black people in the class) so why did it matter if they didn’t get my name right and called my someone else’s? The professor was the person to start this name mix up trend and thought it was funny to call us interchangeable. Made me feel angry, generalized, hurt, disrespected.

caption: I’m a poor brown guy going to a rich white private university. I’m a nice guy who tries to make people happy, but any time I start talking about experiencing racism and classism here, people tell me that my university is the pinnacle of tolerance and that I’m just being too aggressive. They constantly blame me for what I face. I just don’t talk about it anymore.
quote: I’m a poor brown guy going to a rich white private university. I’m a nice guy who tries to make people happy, but any time I start talking about experiencing racism and classism here, people tell me that my university is the pinnacle of tolerance and that I’m just being too aggressive. They constantly blame me for what I face. I just don’t talk about it anymore.

caption: An older white man calls to me as I’m getting out of my car on my street. He walks over and hands me an envelope addressed to someone with an Asian-sounding name. When I say I am not the addressee, he asks me where I can find them.
quote: An older white man calls to me as I’m getting out of my car on my street. He walks over and hands me an envelope addressed to someone with an Asian-sounding name. When I say I am not the addressee, he asks me where I can find them.

caption: Two male subway workers arguing over a construction project in the middle of a group of passengers. This was clearly meant to be a serous insult.
quote: “You can’t just quit in the middle of a fucking job. That’s the sort of thing women do. Are you wearing a skirt?”
actual_quote: You can’t just quit in the middle of a fucking job. That’s the sort of thing women do. Are you wearing a skirt?

caption: After commenting on the “uniqueness” of my common Indian name people choose not to see that Indians are a heterogenous community.
quote: “Oh well, you don’t look Indian.”
actual_quote: Oh well, you don’t look Indian.

caption: Overheard in the hallway, spoken by a girl on her phone. We’d just walked out of a class on Asian American social justice.
quote: “Sorry, I just walked through a horde of loud Asians. So annoying.”
actual_quote: Sorry, I just walked through a horde of loud Asians. So annoying.

caption: In a restaurant in Toronto, a friend introduces me to the owner and mentions that I am from Kenya. The owner asks: “Great! So how’s Kenya? Wild, huh?”
quote: In a restaurant in Toronto, a friend introduces me to the owner and mentions that I am from Kenya. The owner asks: “Great! So how’s Kenya? Wild, huh?”

caption: This little gem of a status popped up on my Facebook newsfeed. 6 people liked it. Disgusted that people I call my friends write this. Disgusted that I have to see this sort of stuff when I’m on my own account.
quote: “Saw two old guys hooking up tonight. CANNOT UNSEE.”
actual_quote: Saw two old guys hooking up tonight. CANNOT UNSEE.

caption: Two guys who walked past an Islamic prayer group at my university.
quote: “Look at all those people on the floor! Pretty funny, isn’t it?”
actual_quote: Look at all those people on the floor! Pretty funny, isn’t it?

caption: Yelled at the TV while watching a football game with young, “liberal” friends.
quote: “BRETT FAVRE LIKES BOYS!”
actual_quote: BRETT FAVRE LIKES BOYS!

caption: A woman at the driver’s licensing place. My mom’s never been married, and this question comes up a lot. Frustrated that there is still a huge societal assumption that all women marry and change their names.
quote: “What was your mother’s last name before she got married?”
actual_quote: What was your mother’s last name before she got married?

caption: We were discussing economic equity in Economics class and the entire classroom, including the females, said that they did not care that they are paid, on average, 30% less than men. They said they were just grateful for the opportunity to work and that it’s a waste of time to fight for equal pay.
quote: We were discussing economic equity in Economics class and the entire classroom, including the females, said that they did not care that they are paid, on average, 30% less than men. They said they were just grateful for the opportunity to work and that it’s a waste of time to fight for equal pay.

caption: My boyfriend when he came over. I have been sick with mono and barely have any energy to shower, let alone shave my legs.
quote: “I guess you haven’t been keeping up with shaving your legs eh?”
actual_quote: I guess you haven’t been keeping up with shaving your legs eh?

caption: My male Grade 12 law teacher.
quote: “So a guy yelling at a woman on the street would be an example of sexual harassment, if the woman chose to make a big deal about it. But you know, if she was dressed a certain way, she might be enjoying that kind of attention.”
actual_quote: So a guy yelling at a woman on the street would be an example of sexual harassment, if the woman chose to make a big deal about it. But you know, if she was dressed a certain way, she might be enjoying that kind of attention.

caption: My freshman year of High School (2008), I’m sitting in my mandatory health class and the topic for the day is rape.  My health teacher, a man in his sixties I believe, tells us that “No means no, although women don’t always mean what they say, so sometimes they say no when they really mean yes.”  This teacher also specifically called me out on questions that I never raised my hand to answer –usually to do with personal anecdotes that I wasn’t interested in sharing - and once implied I looked thin enough to be anorexic (I have Celiac disease).  I was the only girl in a class of males. Made me feel unsafe, exposed, angry.
quote: My freshman year of High School (2008), I’m sitting in my mandatory health class and the topic for the day is rape.  My health teacher, a man in his sixties I believe, tells us that “No means no, although women don’t always mean what they say, so sometimes they say no when they really mean yes.”  This teacher also specifically called me out on questions that I never raised my hand to answer –usually to do with personal anecdotes that I wasn’t interested in sharing - and once implied I looked thin enough to be anorexic (I have Celiac disease).  I was the only girl in a class of males. Made me feel unsafe, exposed, angry.

caption: Two men outside the main building of the Seattle Center.  I’m a woman in my twenties, walking around after a job fair, wearing a skirt and heels.  Made me feel angry, jaded and a little threatened; I left through a different entrance to avoid them.
quote: “Hey, you!  You dropped your smile back there!…Look at you, so pretty, with those legs.  You want a mustache ride?”
actual_quote: Hey, you!  You dropped your smile back there!…Look at you, so pretty, with those legs.  You want a mustache ride?

caption: My white friend after realising that I don’t live in upper middle class white suburbia yet attend a predominately white private school. I am Filipino and live in a community whose median income is about half of the median income of the community he lives in. I felt immediately pissed, defensive, and stunned, because after attending that school for the past three years without any incidents I never thought I’d hear a comment like that from one of my “friends.”
quote: “Do your parents make sacrifices so that you can go to our school?”
actual_quote: Do your parents make sacrifices so that you can go to our school?

caption: What my grandmother said to me, a 14 year old Indian girl. Made me feel worthless, ugly, and unloved.
quote: “Your skin is too dark and your features are too Indian. You will never find a boyfriend with that dark skin of yours. Look at you cousin, she is beautiful and white. Boys line up around the corner to ask her out. Try to look more like her and maybe you’ll find someone.”
actual_quote: Your skin is too dark and your features are too Indian. You will never find a boyfriend with that dark skin of yours. Look at you cousin, she is beautiful and white. Boys line up around the corner to ask her out. Try to look more like her and maybe you’ll find someone.

caption: Said to me by a lighter-skinned straight-haired woman of color. Made me feel ugly.
quote: “You see, that’s the difference between you and me. I have good hair, and you have nigger hair.”
actual_quote: You see, that’s the difference between you and me. I have good hair, and you have nigger hair.

caption: Someone I care about was almost raped by her best friend, but she managed to escape. When she told her mother what happened, her mother was disgusted. But not by him or what had happened, but by her. Her mother called her a whore and told her if she doesn’t want that to happen then she should wear more conservative clothes. (story told here with her permission). She says she felt angry and hated that her mother’s words made her feel worthless.
quote: Someone I care about was almost raped by her best friend, but she managed to escape. When she told her mother what happened, her mother was disgusted. But not by him or what had happened, but by her. Her mother called her a whore and told her if she doesn’t want that to happen then she should wear more conservative clothes. (story told here with her permission). She says she felt angry and hated that her mother’s words made her feel worthless.

caption: I went to a party where, before I had even said hello, a man loudly said “You got fat in college!” Everyone at the party heard and started making comments, such as “No, you can’t say those things. Girls only want to hear how skinny they are.”  I just stood there in silence, then left the party soon after.  I felt humiliated and powerless; I could either be a killjoy for everyone or suffer in silence, and I did the latter.
quote: I went to a party where, before I had even said hello, a man loudly said “You got fat in college!” Everyone at the party heard and started making comments, such as “No, you can’t say those things. Girls only want to hear how skinny they are.”  I just stood there in silence, then left the party soon after.  I felt humiliated and powerless; I could either be a killjoy for everyone or suffer in silence, and I did the latter.

caption: My female friend and I (13 years old) walk around the mall in India in shorts and t-shirts and get cat-called at by men up to twice our age. One touches my butt and attempts to touch my boobs so I slap him. He then tells me it is my fault he felt me up because my clothes were too provocative. Made me feel objectified, hurt, violated.
quote: My female friend and I (13 years old) walk around the mall in India in shorts and t-shirts and get cat-called at by men up to twice our age. One touches my butt and attempts to touch my boobs so I slap him. He then tells me it is my fault he felt me up because my clothes were too provocative. Made me feel objectified, hurt, violated.

caption: My peers to me all the time. Makes me feel erased.
quote: “Stop trying to say you’re some kind of minority just because you’re mixed. You look white, okay?!”
actual_quote: Stop trying to say you’re some kind of minority just because you’re mixed. You look white, okay?!

quote: “Are you sure you have the right room number? This is the *honors* section.”
actual_quote: Are you sure you have the right room number? This is the *honors* section.

caption: Said to me, a woman, by an older man when I was just a teenager and pulled up to fill my car at a full service gas station. Made me feel humiliated and ashamed, like it wasn’t enough that I was paying with money but that I had to pay with a smile. It’s been years and I still look back on it and feel upset that it happened.
quote: “Come on, smile for me. I won’t pump your gas until you give me a smile!”
actual_quote: Come on, smile for me. I won’t pump your gas until you give me a smile!

caption: In school from a guy friend of mine, after being the only student in the class to receive 100% on a math test. It made me feel like I was expected to be stupid because of my body.
quote: “You’re good at math for a girl.”
actual_quote: You’re good at math for a girl.

caption: My friend. I am an African-American woman. It made me feel like I couldn’t be pretty because I’m dark-skinned.
quote: “My mom used to make me put on Fair and Lovely. She just wanted me to be pretty!”
actual_quote: My mom used to make me put on Fair and Lovely. She just wanted me to be pretty!

caption: I (female) have problems with my ovaries that mean I’m most likely infertile. When my gyno starts talking about taking steps to allow me to bear children one day, I stop her, explaining that I would never want to. She tells me to call her in ten to twenty years. I felt that my doctor didn’t respect the choices I made with my body. If I could bear children, it would require extensive work, time, and money for what would probably be a miscarriage so I’m going to adopt if I decide I want children. That this didn’t even come up as an option made me feel like I was reduced to my uterus, ovaries, and their capabilities.
quote: I (female) have problems with my ovaries that mean I’m most likely infertile. When my gyno starts talking about taking steps to allow me to bear children one day, I stop her, explaining that I would never want to. She tells me to call her in ten to twenty years. I felt that my doctor didn’t respect the choices I made with my body. If I could bear children, it would require extensive work, time, and money for what would probably be a miscarriage so I’m going to adopt if I decide I want children. That this didn’t even come up as an option made me feel like I was reduced to my uterus, ovaries, and their capabilities.

caption: Said to me over and over again throughout my life by friends, coworkers, and strangers. My parents are Oglala Lakota and Mohawk/Iroquois respectively, with some French and German.
quote: “I know you’re something. So what are you exactly?”
actual_quote: I know you’re something. So what are you exactly?

caption: We’re playing Pictionary in my environmental science class, and a student draws a basketball player and a bucket-shaped object on the board. No one is able to guess what environmental science concept he’s supposed to be depicting, but then he explains himself. “It’s a KFC bucket, my word was HIV.”
quote: We’re playing Pictionary in my environmental science class, and a student draws a basketball player and a bucket-shaped object on the board. No one is able to guess what environmental science concept he’s supposed to be depicting, but then he explains himself. “It’s a KFC bucket, my word was HIV.”

caption: A slender co-worker. I am overweight. At work. Made me feel ashamed and angry.
quote: “If I go to eat somewhere, and there are a bunch of fat people in line, I leave. I just lose my appetite.”
actual_quote: If I go to eat somewhere, and there are a bunch of fat people in line, I leave. I just lose my appetite.

caption: I’m a 32-year-old engineer, and I pipe up coolant for beer festivals as a hobby. But I’m a *woman*, so some little plumber thinks it’s impressive I can do really simple little home-maintenance jobs.
quote: “I’m impressed you managed to fit the ball valve at all!”
actual_quote: I’m impressed you managed to fit the ball valve at all!

quote: Hey, I am an artist preparing for a performance piece on microaggressions and the marginalization and otherization of different social groups and I was wondering if you would pass it along that I'm trying to collect audio recordings of microaggressions [whether reenacted or actual]  and  similar experiences. I would really appreciate it if you would pass this along so people can contact me via tumblr for more information.  Thank you for your time. -LobolitaBlanca

caption: In class during a lecture about a band in which one member self-harmed. Made me feel humiliated and misunderstood. Added to my feeling of being stupid and attention-seeking.
quote: “I think people who cut themselves are stupid. Why would you do that? Do they actually think it will make their problems go away?”
actual_quote: I think people who cut themselves are stupid. Why would you do that? Do they actually think it will make their problems go away?

caption: Matthew Desmond and Mustafa Emirbayer, What is Racial Domination?
quote: “To define racism only through extreme groups and their extreme acts is akin to defining weather only through hurricanes. Hurricanes are certainly a type of weather pattern - a harsh and brutal type - but so too are mild rainfalls, light breezes, and sunny days. Likewise, racism is much broader than violence and epithets. It also comes in quieter, everyday-ordinary forms.”
actual_quote: To define racism only through extreme groups and their extreme acts is akin to defining weather only through hurricanes. Hurricanes are certainly a type of weather pattern - a harsh and brutal type - but so too are mild rainfalls, light breezes, and sunny days. Likewise, racism is much broader than violence and epithets. It also comes in quieter, everyday-ordinary forms.

caption: Which princesses are up and center?

I am sitting in a sophomore study hall working on math homework with one of my friends, and the boy next to me asks if we need any help, since he knows “girls usually have trouble with math”. He points to his Geometry textbook.  I am working on BC Calculus homework, my friend on Multivariable Calculus.
quote: I am sitting in a sophomore study hall working on math homework with one of my friends, and the boy next to me asks if we need any help, since he knows “girls usually have trouble with math”. He points to his Geometry textbook.  I am working on BC Calculus homework, my friend on Multivariable Calculus.

caption: Was biking through town when two women yelled “Konichiwa!” at me…
quote:
Was biking through town when two women yelled “Konichiwa!” at me…
I’m Vietnamese. And I was born in California.
(Also, where’s the female solidarity?)

caption: This morning, the Today show did a segment on foods from around the world. They highlighted one specific food item from each place.
quote:
This morning, the Today show did a segment on foods from around the world. They highlighted one specific food item from each place.
Some of the places named: India, Scotland, and Africa.
I hope I’m not the only one who finds this problematic.

caption: I was working and I engaged in a conversation with an older white male while he was waiting for his wife to finish shopping. Mid-conversation he looks at me and says “What are you?” I didn’t really understand his question so I said “Excuse me ?” He says “What are you, where from?” I said “oh I was born here my parents are from Mexico I’m Mexican ” Man: well you sure are pretty for being one.
quote: I was working and I engaged in a conversation with an older white male while he was waiting for his wife to finish shopping. Mid-conversation he looks at me and says “What are you?” I didn’t really understand his question so I said “Excuse me ?” He says “What are you, where from?” I said “oh I was born here my parents are from Mexico I’m Mexican ” Man: well you sure are pretty for being one.

caption: Entered an informal backgammon tournament (8 players, all men but me) and won my first round. Was told by another player that I was “good…for a woman.” My vanquished opponent called him out on that – and noted that it was likely the attitude why more women don’t play.
quote: Entered an informal backgammon tournament (8 players, all men but me) and won my first round. Was told by another player that I was “good…for a woman.” My vanquished opponent called him out on that – and noted that it was likely the attitude why more women don’t play.

caption: I am a woman. I have a spanish/latin background. I cleaned houses for many years. I now wear jeans and a t-shirt, and sneakers most of the time. So when I retired I joined the local Friends of the Library. One woman there treats me like I am lesser than her. She won’t speak to me, greet me, or smile at me. She treats all the other volunteers with dignity but me. She assigns all the heavy lifting and grunt work to me, like I am her servant.
quote: I am a woman. I have a spanish/latin background. I cleaned houses for many years. I now wear jeans and a t-shirt, and sneakers most of the time. So when I retired I joined the local Friends of the Library. One woman there treats me like I am lesser than her. She won’t speak to me, greet me, or smile at me. She treats all the other volunteers with dignity but me. She assigns all the heavy lifting and grunt work to me, like I am her servant.
“I’m probably such a racist, but a black man dressed as Santa is just wrong.”
actual_quote: I’m probably such a racist, but a black man dressed as Santa is just wrong.

quote: “Don’t worry she’s just bi-curious. She’ll grow out of it.”
actual_quote: Don’t worry she’s just bi-curious. She’ll grow out of it.

caption: Being called “hearing impared,” instead of deaf or hard of hearing.
quote:
Being called “hearing impared,” instead of deaf or hard of hearing.
The term “hearing impaired” seems silly to be upset over, but when used over and over to describe you, you begin to believe that you are indeed broken instead of just different. I fight against the use of this word everyday.

caption: The color “nude” looks like this.
This was told to a student in my class who wants to do her class project on organizations doing after-school programs for undocumented children and families.
quote: “Well, I mean I’m sure that at least some of them are illegals, right?”
actual_quote: Well, I mean I’m sure that at least some of them are illegals, right?

caption: Comment made during a conversation about contemporary racism.
quote: “Racism is only a problem now because minorities continue to think they’re oppressed.”
actual_quote: Racism is only a problem now because minorities continue to think they’re oppressed.

caption: In my AP European History course, our text book is obviously solely about European history. It’s titled, “A History of the Modern World.”
quote: In my AP European History course, our text book is obviously solely about European history. It’s titled, “A History of the Modern World.”

caption: Some food for thought so we can all tell MANY stories!!
quote: A talk on representation that we love from novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie

caption: At my school study hall in suburban USA. It made me feel stereotyped and ostracized for being a poor African American.
quote: “I hate going into the city. There are so many black people and it’s so ghetto… Not to be racist or anything.”
actual_quote: I hate going into the city. There are so many black people and it’s so ghetto… Not to be racist or anything.

caption: I’m a Mohawk woman, born and bred on a reserve in Ontario, yet the number of times white people say to me, “Oh, you’re Indian?? What percentage are you?” is astonishing. I would never presume to ask anyone what percentage their blood quantum is, yet perfect strangers feel it’s okay to ask me this all the time. Makes me feel surprised and disgusted.
quote: I’m a Mohawk woman, born and bred on a reserve in Ontario, yet the number of times white people say to me, “Oh, you’re Indian?? What percentage are you?” is astonishing. I would never presume to ask anyone what percentage their blood quantum is, yet perfect strangers feel it’s okay to ask me this all the time. Makes me feel surprised and disgusted.

caption: I get asked this almost every day. I am a Latin American living in Germany.  I also have people come up to me asking me things in languages I don’t understand. Often, it’s strangers on the street thinking that because I look different, I will talk to any stranger who gives me attention. It makes me feel as if I didn’t have a right to a certain personal space and distance. It makes me feel unsafe and forever labeled as a stranger.
quote: “Are you from India?”
actual_quote: Are you from India?

caption: Bumper sticker.  Metro Detroit.
quote: “Ford: Built With Tools, Not With Chopsticks”
actual_quote: Ford: Built With Tools, Not With Chopsticks

caption: At my school, the Introduction to Native Americans class, which covers the history of Native Americans from pre-Contact to present day, does not count towards the United States History general education requirement.
