I felt like I only got the pass because he wanted my number, and I felt pressured to comply so I didn’t lose the pass, which I could not afford to do. I wasn’t asking for a date, buddy, and you didn’t do me any favors by following the parking permit regulations.  Female, late twenties, last week. Took place in a parking authority office. I felt patronized, belittled, and incredibly annoyed.

caption: My history teacher gave the class a bonus question asking who the owner of the Atlanta Falcons NFL team was (The school is located near Atlanta). After a few people in the class complained that it wasn’t a fair question, my teacher replies “Okay, okay, would you like for me to create a girl’s bonus question?” I am a 17 year old girl and am a sports fanatic. I probably know more about hockey than each member of the class combined.   High school American History class. Is it just a given that girls are not passionate and/or knowledgeable sports fans?
quote: My history teacher gave the class a bonus question asking who the owner of the Atlanta Falcons NFL team was (The school is located near Atlanta). After a few people in the class complained that it wasn’t a fair question, my teacher replies “Okay, okay, would you like for me to create a girl’s bonus question?” I am a 17 year old girl and am a sports fanatic. I probably know more about hockey than each member of the class combined.   High school American History class. Is it just a given that girls are not passionate and/or knowledgeable sports fans?

caption: Moviegoer at the theater where I had to wear a name tag. I was in a bad mood and told him I wasn’t paid enough to smile for him. Then I crossed my eyes and blew a raspberry so he would take it as a joke. Made me frustrated that, because I was working, I had to play nice. Startled that he addressed me by name. Patronized.
quote: “I’d like two tickets to the next show and a smile, Caitlin.”
actual_quote: I’d like two tickets to the next show and a smile, Caitlin.

caption: I informed some of my  friends that I get extended time on a high school final because of a mild learning disability that I have struggled with for my entire life. They proceeded to tell me that I am “lucky” for having extended time, that they are “jealous” that they do not also get it or that it’s “not fair” that I have that privilege when most students don’t. I felt misunderstood, embarrassed, and alone.
quote: I informed some of my  friends that I get extended time on a high school final because of a mild learning disability that I have struggled with for my entire life. They proceeded to tell me that I am “lucky” for having extended time, that they are “jealous” that they do not also get it or that it’s “not fair” that I have that privilege when most students don’t. I felt misunderstood, embarrassed, and alone.

caption: Living with your parents always presents a raft of problems, which is not made easier when you’re transgendered.  For example, their refusal to use your (now legal) name or (now legal) sex when talking to or about you.  Despite the fact both have been changed for years.
quote:
Living with your parents always presents a raft of problems, which is not made easier when you’re transgendered.  For example, their refusal to use your (now legal) name or (now legal) sex when talking to or about you.  Despite the fact both have been changed for years.
Thanks for helping with my depression, anxiety, and insecurity!  Nice to know I’m supported in the way that least inconveniences you! I shouldn’t complain, though; my sister believes that I’m ‘too young’ to know my own gender and shouldn’t try to transition until she deems me old enough. Makes me feel isolated, and depressed.

caption: In high school we need to take a practical art to graduate. I decided to take woodworking to fulfill my requirement. When I went to the counselor’s office to get my schedule approved he kept trying to change my mind and starts recommending other classes instead of woodworking. He recommended ‘Childcare and Development’, 'Cooking’, and finally, 'Basic Automotive for Women.’ After I kept saying I want to take woodworking he replies with, “I don’t understand why a pretty girl like you wants to take a class. You have 5 days to drop and switch to another class if you can’t handle it.” I was 17 years old, 2007, Missouri, High School. I felt disrespected. I felt small. I felt worthless. I felt abnormal.  I feel punished for being a girl.
quote: In high school we need to take a practical art to graduate. I decided to take woodworking to fulfill my requirement. When I went to the counselor’s office to get my schedule approved he kept trying to change my mind and starts recommending other classes instead of woodworking. He recommended ‘Childcare and Development’, 'Cooking’, and finally, 'Basic Automotive for Women.’ After I kept saying I want to take woodworking he replies with, “I don’t understand why a pretty girl like you wants to take a class. You have 5 days to drop and switch to another class if you can’t handle it.” I was 17 years old, 2007, Missouri, High School. I felt disrespected. I felt small. I felt worthless. I felt abnormal.  I feel punished for being a girl.

caption: Watching the pilot of “The Next Food Network Star,” a young chef who happens to have a Mexican heritage cooks French food. The judges advise her that she should cook Mexican food instead. LIKE HER NATIONALITY IS ALL SHE HAS TO OFFER. Made me feel like I will never be more than what you see.
quote: Watching the pilot of “The Next Food Network Star,” a young chef who happens to have a Mexican heritage cooks French food. The judges advise her that she should cook Mexican food instead. LIKE HER NATIONALITY IS ALL SHE HAS TO OFFER. Made me feel like I will never be more than what you see.

caption: I bring up how masculinity/femininity are culturally specific and white masc/femme notions are talked about as universal. I use an example about how in western contexts, Asian men are considered more effeminate/emasculated, and how that’s used as a means to further racism.
quote:
I bring up how masculinity/femininity are culturally specific and white masc/femme notions are talked about as universal. I use an example about how in western contexts, Asian men are considered more effeminate/emasculated, and how that’s used as a means to further racism.
White person #1 responds: I love Asians, Asians are hot!White person #2: Yeah, if it weren’t for Asians, there wouldn’t be so many cool TV shows!
I raise my eyebrows, sigh and look down. At a female masculinities discussion at a queer youth event, I’m Chinese and genderqueer. I felt like they missed the point completely and their reaction implied that our existence and value is purely for white people’s entertainment.

caption: Any and every time someone mentions that you can’t have children unless you’re fertile, cisgendered, and in a heterosexual relationship.
quote:
Any and every time someone mentions that you can’t have children unless you’re fertile, cisgendered, and in a heterosexual relationship.
I’m adopted.

caption: While discussing the summer weather. I’m from Bogotá - the average temperature is 60°F.  I feel like nobody in the States bothers to understand that Latin@s are not just one monolithic entity.
quote: “Oh, but you’re Latin, so you must love the heat!”
actual_quote: Oh, but you’re Latin, so you must love the heat!

caption: I worked as a data entry clerk which required me to type. I type one-handed because I’m hemiplegic.
quote:
I worked as a data entry clerk which required me to type. I type one-handed because I’m hemiplegic.
A coworker broke her arm and was on sick leave for several weeks. When she returned, she was only doing non-computer related tasks. One day she cornered me in the bathroom and told me how sorry she was for me. She couldn’t imagine what it must be like for me, since she knew she was useless without the use of both hands.

caption: A man at a party recently asked me if I carry my cane for fashion purposes, then grilled me about my medical condition after I said no.  I’m a 27 year old woman with a neurological condition that causes pain in my legs, and my cane is the aluminum/rubber sort one would find at a pharmacy. Made me feel confused, humiliated, misunderstood.
quote: A man at a party recently asked me if I carry my cane for fashion purposes, then grilled me about my medical condition after I said no.  I’m a 27 year old woman with a neurological condition that causes pain in my legs, and my cane is the aluminum/rubber sort one would find at a pharmacy. Made me feel confused, humiliated, misunderstood.

caption: “All my Asian friends are here! Wait, where’s L? She should be here too.”Said by my friend, who is white and ignores the fact that L and I have no common interests. But yes, we are both Asian. When I bring this up, she implies I take myself too seriously. Makes me feel like a collectible.
quote: “All my Asian friends are here! Wait, where’s L? She should be here too.”Said by my friend, who is white and ignores the fact that L and I have no common interests. But yes, we are both Asian. When I bring this up, she implies I take myself too seriously. Makes me feel like a collectible.

caption: I may not be white, but my home is still only a few blocks away. Not across an ocean/border, thanks.
quote: “Go home.”
actual_quote: Go home.

caption: A neighbor upon hearing my plans for after graduation. He assumed that I wanted to have children and that I wouldn’t be able to handle kids and a career as a woman. Made me feel invalidated, incapable and forced to meet expectations I don’t want.
quote: “Yeah, well, medical school and being a doctor can be really hard for women.  It’s hard to manage that and have a family.”
actual_quote: Yeah, well, medical school and being a doctor can be really hard for women.  It’s hard to manage that and have a family.

caption: A white man who felt compelled to say this while walking past me and my sister today in Marina Del Rey. That’s racist! I couldn’t believe what he had said at first. I still feel incredulous, but now also angry, frustrated, and upset that we appear so worthless in someone’s eyes that he felt like he could just toss out a stupid comment like that.
quote: “Me love you long time.”
actual_quote: Me love you long time.

caption: quixotess:Image description: Three panels from American Born Chinese by Gene Luen Yang. A young adolescent boy stands in front of a classroom full of white students. The narration says “On the morning we arrived, with the scent of my old home still lingering in my clothes, I was sent off to Mrs. Greeder’s third grade class at Mayflower Elementary school.The white teacher says “Class, I’d like us all to give a warm Mayflower Elementary welcome to your new friend and classmate Jin Jang!”Jin says “Jin Wang.”The teacher says “Jin Wang! He and his family recently moved to our neighborhood all the way from China!”Jin says “San Francisco.”The teacher says “San Francisco!”The third panel is from Jin’s point of view and shows Jin’s white classmates looking at him, maybe staring, some frowning. One frowning boy in front has his hand raised. End of image description.

A white friend said this to me when we were discussing Halloween costumes. I’m a black female. She implied that you had to be white in order to be smurfette despite the fact that smurfette is blue. It made me feel angry. It was as if she was saying when you have dark skinned your limited in what you can do but when your skin is light you can do anything.
quote: “You can’t be smurfette, you’re black.”
actual_quote: You can’t be smurfette, you’re black.

caption: My grandfather does not speak very good English, and lived in China for most of his life. I however, am half Polish. He was keeping me company in the store where I work, when a Caucasian lady came in. After trying to talk to him multiple times, she grabbed her items and I rang them up for her. As she left, she commented on my “great English.” I was born and raised in the United States.  I am 16, June 2011, in Michigan. Made me feel confused, upset, defensive.
quote: My grandfather does not speak very good English, and lived in China for most of his life. I however, am half Polish. He was keeping me company in the store where I work, when a Caucasian lady came in. After trying to talk to him multiple times, she grabbed her items and I rang them up for her. As she left, she commented on my “great English.” I was born and raised in the United States.  I am 16, June 2011, in Michigan. Made me feel confused, upset, defensive.

caption: A friend about referring to me as a tranny. Made me feel awful. Like calling me slurs is okay because I’m trans and that I’m overreacting for being hurt by it.
quote: “She’s too sensitive. Why should she get upset at me for calling her what she is?”
actual_quote: She’s too sensitive. Why should she get upset at me for calling her what she is?

caption: (via clientsfromhell)
quote: “Is there any way to make it so that ebonics shows up under the Google Translate button? I’m curious to know how black people interact with the site.”
actual_quote: Is there any way to make it so that ebonics shows up under the Google Translate button? I’m curious to know how black people interact with the site.

caption: My ex boyfriend when we started dating.
quote: “I like that you’re bi because it means you’d be open to a threesome.”
actual_quote: I like that you’re bi because it means you’d be open to a threesome.

caption: When I was little, my aunts always gave me Barbies even though they knew I disliked dolls. Now they give me make-up and chick lit hoping that I’ll “grow up” and stop being a “tomboy.” I am a 24-year-old woman. It makes me feel frustrated, as if the only important thing about me is my gender, not my personality.
quote: When I was little, my aunts always gave me Barbies even though they knew I disliked dolls. Now they give me make-up and chick lit hoping that I’ll “grow up” and stop being a “tomboy.” I am a 24-year-old woman. It makes me feel frustrated, as if the only important thing about me is my gender, not my personality.

caption: My sister, when I told her about a bad experience I had with a girl. I’m a 20-year-old woman from the UK. Made me feel invalidated, doubtful, ashamed.
quote: “Maybe you’re just not really a lesbian.”
actual_quote: Maybe you’re just not really a lesbian.

caption: Hey Fellow,[blah blah blah]Take care, Sir!
quote:
Hey Fellow,[blah blah blah]Take care, Sir!
The salutation and closing of an email I got in response to a craigslist ad in the Musical Instruments section. I had posted a want to buy ad that said “I am in a touring band and need a new gigbag for my bass.”
Apparently only men can be in touring bands and play bass. I am a 23 year old (trans) woman using the internet, totally anonymous and no gendering anything was in my post! Made me feel invisible, misgendered, and like my musicianship is suspect.

caption: In Sephora I asked a woman to help me find a nude shade of lipstick for myself. She brought a pale beige color and the other resembling a white person’s skin. When i asked her that I wanted one that match my own skin tone, she exclaimed “Oh you should have just said you wanted a natural lip color!”
quote:
In Sephora I asked a woman to help me find a nude shade of lipstick for myself. She brought a pale beige color and the other resembling a white person’s skin. When i asked her that I wanted one that match my own skin tone, she exclaimed “Oh you should have just said you wanted a natural lip color!”
I am half African American and half Native American with a milkybrown color. Nude does not equal natural for me.

caption: Facebook status. I am glad to see that the first comment “excuse me?” got five likes.
quote: “25 job applications done. 0 responses. being a white male in the 21st century sucks.”
actual_quote: 25 job applications done. 0 responses. being a white male in the 21st century sucks.

caption: My mother, when I came out to her as genderqueer. Made me feel pigeonholed… especially since my identity has been tending more towards female over time.
quote: “I have to admit I am relieved you’re not taking it all the way to becoming female - I think that would have been an adjustment I’d have a great deal of difficulty making.”
actual_quote: I have to admit I am relieved you’re not taking it all the way to becoming female - I think that would have been an adjustment I’d have a great deal of difficulty making.

caption: “You look pretty today. What a pretty smile you have. Awww, and it looks like you have some work to do.” A fellow customer, a man in his 50s, at the hardware store, on looking at me and then in my cart. He proceeded to ask me about my “project” and whether or not I had anyone to help me with it.
quote:
“You look pretty today. What a pretty smile you have. Awww, and it looks like you have some work to do.” A fellow customer, a man in his 50s, at the hardware store, on looking at me and then in my cart. He proceeded to ask me about my “project” and whether or not I had anyone to help me with it.
I hate shopping at the hardware store. If I’m there with my husband, I’m ignored. If I’m there by myself, it’s like I’m fair game. I’m a 26-year-old female, June 2011. I felt patronized and objectified.

caption: Shouted out to me by a male passerby as I was pumping gas into my Ninja. I just laughed at him. People that are that ignorant aren’t worth my anger or humiliation.
quote: “A WOMAN ON A MOTORCYCLE?!! HAHAHAHAHA!”
actual_quote: A WOMAN ON A MOTORCYCLE?!! HAHAHAHAHA!

caption: I am of both European and Middle Eastern descent. If I don’t look “too Arab,” then I get to be Caucasian/white. My partner says things like “Your people aren’t white!” and “You’re so olive.” Being considered not white is a non-issue for me, but his racial attitudes (even if he’s joking) make me “other,” as if whiteness is the pinnacle and it’s an insult to be denied membership to the race.
quote:
I am of both European and Middle Eastern descent. If I don’t look “too Arab,” then I get to be Caucasian/white. My partner says things like “Your people aren’t white!” and “You’re so olive.” Being considered not white is a non-issue for me, but his racial attitudes (even if he’s joking) make me “other,” as if whiteness is the pinnacle and it’s an insult to be denied membership to the race.
Unfortunately, I find myself sometimes giving in to his judgment. I wear sunscreen to protect my skin like everyone else, but I also use it to keep my skin tone the way it is and not get darker. I love the winter because I can almost get as pale as him. Through his comments about my olive-toned skin, I have subconsciously learned how to hate it and therefore hate myself.

caption: I’m taking a film photography course at my college. In the dark room while developing film, these two other girls were in there as well.  One girl turns to the other and says, “you look dark in this photo!” The other girl responds with, “Oh? Am I fabulously tan or hood dark?”
quote:
I’m taking a film photography course at my college. In the dark room while developing film, these two other girls were in there as well.  One girl turns to the other and says, “you look dark in this photo!” The other girl responds with, “Oh? Am I fabulously tan or hood dark?”
I’m a 22 year old, brown skinned African American girl. In school in Maryland. I felt out of place and isolated.

caption: While we’ve defined “microaggressions” in our About and FAQ, it’s sometimes difficult to categorize every submission we receive. We sometimes slip up on our own definitions and work constantly to improve our editing.
quote:
While we’ve defined “microaggressions” in our About and FAQ, it’s sometimes difficult to categorize every submission we receive. We sometimes slip up on our own definitions and work constantly to improve our editing.
We’ve posted a wide range of submissions, about different identities and situations, and are often met with support and critique. We want to open up this discussion thread to hear what you have to say about defining “microaggression”.
What does a “microaggression” mean to you? Does this blog’s definition leave something out? Is it too broad? Is it relevant for those who belong to privileged identities? Can I submit a microaggression if I don’t identify with the identity being addressed? (Also addressed here.)

caption: My grandfather forwards me an email called “Classes for Women Taught By Men” and I’m foolish enough to open it. It features gems such as :
quote:
My grandfather forwards me an email called “Classes for Women Taught By Men” and I’m foolish enough to open it. It features gems such as :
I wonder what he thinks of me as a woman then. Am I stupid, constantly “menstrual.” Do I, like all women apparently, need to shut up. Made me feel sad & angry.

caption: public boolean isGirlCute(){if(isComputerScienceGirl()){return false;}…}
quote:
public boolean isGirlCute(){if(isComputerScienceGirl()){return false;}…}
I see waaaay too many jokes like this on Facebook about the lack of “attractive computer science girls.” I am a female computer science major (in a small private university), and I initially wanted to try to join this group of friends, who are some of the best CS students in the school. Makes me feel ashamed and disappointed.

caption: Chinese-Singaporean colleague of Han descent. At work in a school in Singapore. Made me feel shocked. Nauseous.
quote: “Oh, you’re not like our other Indian colleague. You’re light skinned, you’re okay. They just talk about how brown they are.”
actual_quote: Oh, you’re not like our other Indian colleague. You’re light skinned, you’re okay. They just talk about how brown they are.

caption: Said by white male. I am a freshman in college. Made me feel as though I should be intimidating because I’m black.
quote: “You’re really un-intimidating for a black guy.”
actual_quote: You’re really un-intimidating for a black guy.

caption: I’m the only woman in the engineering department at a U.S. manufacturing facility. I walk into a meeting after repairing a machine in our grimy production lines. My clothes are filthy. I have black grease on my hands and arms and (as it turns out) a little on my face.
quote:
I’m the only woman in the engineering department at a U.S. manufacturing facility. I walk into a meeting after repairing a machine in our grimy production lines. My clothes are filthy. I have black grease on my hands and arms and (as it turns out) a little on my face.
My boss: Hey, you’ve got some mascara on your cheek.
Last week, eastern U.S. Made me feel like I’m not taken seriously as an engineer, that my boss only sees me as “the girl” on our team.
“You’re pretty for a Tamil girl.”
actual_quote: You’re pretty for a Tamil girl.

caption: A police officer as he enters a restaurant with mostly non-white employees. Followed by laughter from our (white) manager.
quote: “Immigration!”
actual_quote: Immigration!

caption: A cisgendered gay man after finding out that I - also a gay man - am trans. Makes me feel frustrated, scrutinized and invisable, like my maleness is contingent on my ability to “pass.” Made me feel like “The deceptive trans person.”
quote: “Oh my god! Wow. Just. Wow! That’s really unbelivable, I never would have guessed!”
actual_quote: Oh my god! Wow. Just. Wow! That’s really unbelivable, I never would have guessed!

caption: Male customer to me, a 25-year-old female - and I can assure you the equipment I was using will work equally well regardless of the operator’s mood.
quote: “It won’t work if you don’t smile!”
actual_quote: It won’t work if you don’t smile!

caption: Said to me by another Latino after helping him with a math problem in an honors class.  I am extremely shy so most people who meet me assume I’m a immigrant who can’t speak English.
quote: “You’re smart for a Mexican.”
actual_quote: You’re smart for a Mexican.

caption: A person who claims to be a trans ally said this to me.
quote: “I won’t ever use the word ‘cisgender’ -  it’s a useless word.”
actual_quote: I won’t ever use the word ‘cisgender’ -  it’s a useless word.

caption: A Boston cop, to my friends and I (women, early twenties) after separating a woman and her abuser outside of a bar. We try to see if she’s all right and offer her some resources, but she walks away in tears. We stand there, stunned, and the cop offers us that little gem.  He will never know what it’s like to be a woman on a dark street at night, and the extent to which we cannot relax. Boston Common on the night of the Bruins game-heavy police presence. Made me feel unsafe, incredulous, hyperaware of rape culture.
quote: “Relax ladies, it’s no big deal!”
actual_quote: Relax ladies, it’s no big deal!

caption: An older man is paying with credit at my register. When I (28 year old woman) quickly take his card to swipe it, he laughs and says, “Well, look at you grabbing at my credit card!  Isn’t that just like a woman!” I look away, visibly disgusted and mutter “what…” and keep working. He seems abashed and then meekly croaks, “It was a joke… sorry.”
quote:
An older man is paying with credit at my register. When I (28 year old woman) quickly take his card to swipe it, he laughs and says, “Well, look at you grabbing at my credit card!  Isn’t that just like a woman!” I look away, visibly disgusted and mutter “what…” and keep working. He seems abashed and then meekly croaks, “It was a joke… sorry.”
Made me feel belittled and stereotyped, but kind of amused at how he backed down after he saw my reaction.

caption: Waiter to my male friend after we asked for separate checks. As a queer woman, this offended me on various levels.
quote: “Seriously, you’re not going to pay for her?”
actual_quote: Seriously, you’re not going to pay for her?

caption: Advertisement for bake sale tomorrow by UC Berkeley College Republicans. Photo via Colorlines.
Gay man in front of me (trans).
quote: “Hot tranny mess.”
actual_quote: Hot tranny mess.

caption: Cisgender hetero coworker to me, a genderqueer lesbian. Made me remember why I’m not out at work.
quote: “If someone called me feminine, it’d be like calling me a faggot. And if I called some chick masculine, well… that’s just unfortunate for her ugly ass.”
actual_quote: If someone called me feminine, it’d be like calling me a faggot. And if I called some chick masculine, well… that’s just unfortunate for her ugly ass.

caption: I’ve had so many people get excited when I start speaking and they see that I don’t have an accent. And I’ve had so many people ask where I’m ‘really’ from. I am Asian American.
quote: I’ve had so many people get excited when I start speaking and they see that I don’t have an accent. And I’ve had so many people ask where I’m ‘really’ from. I am Asian American.

caption: Happy Meal toy promotions have recently been separated into “girl” and “boy.” The ones I want are labeled “boy toys.” Guess only boys like video games and Pokémon.
quote: Happy Meal toy promotions have recently been separated into “girl” and “boy.” The ones I want are labeled “boy toys.” Guess only boys like video games and Pokémon.

caption: Made me feel like my interest in cooking is a given, and all the work I’ve put into getting better was irrelevant. And also like my arrangement with my roommate (I make dessert, roommate makes dinner) wasn’t a thing–we were both fooling around in the kitchen, right? It’s not like we were doing totally different things that require totally different skill sets.
quote: “Look at the women, fooling around in the kitchen.”
actual_quote: Look at the women, fooling around in the kitchen.

caption: I found some sort of comedy club called Tourettes Without Regrets. As far as I can tell, it has nothing to do with actual Tourette’s. I feel as if the condition I suffer from daily as been completely co-opted and turned into a joke.
quote: I found some sort of comedy club called Tourettes Without Regrets. As far as I can tell, it has nothing to do with actual Tourette’s. I feel as if the condition I suffer from daily as been completely co-opted and turned into a joke.

caption: White male classmate on bus who accidentally bumps into me (an Indian American girl) while I’m sitting in one of the seats. In high school & made me feel angry, upset, dehumanized.
quote: “Sorry if you can’t get married now!”
actual_quote: Sorry if you can’t get married now!

caption: David Starkey, historian, blaming English riots on black culture. I was stunned.
quote: “The whites have become black.”
actual_quote: The whites have become black.

caption: When I search on Google for “LGBTQ” and it corrects my search as “LGBT”.
quote: When I search on Google for “LGBTQ” and it corrects my search as “LGBT”.

caption: Said to me, a twenty-something girl, by a forty-something man at the gym as I hobbled off of the treadmill. Made me feel uncomfortable and threatened.
quote: “Haha! You look like my girl did last night when I was done with her!”
actual_quote: Haha! You look like my girl did last night when I was done with her!

caption: While attending an American graduate program in China I was told numerous times by male American students that they prefer to date the local women because American women are too big/aggressive/slutty. 27 years old, 2008, Nanjing, graduate school filled with white expats. Made me feel aggressive, slutty, and large.
quote: While attending an American graduate program in China I was told numerous times by male American students that they prefer to date the local women because American women are too big/aggressive/slutty. 27 years old, 2008, Nanjing, graduate school filled with white expats. Made me feel aggressive, slutty, and large.

caption: Administrator on a college campus. Made me feel horrified, sad, concerned for students.
quote: “I had a chude moment-I didn’t know if it was a chick or a dude.”
actual_quote: I had a chude moment-I didn’t know if it was a chick or a dude.

caption: I have to get used to game design and programming seminars discussed using “he”, “him” and other male pronouns in English. I’m a woman who both creates and enjoys games. Makes me feel alone, but also happy that my native language has gender neutral pronouns.
quote: I have to get used to game design and programming seminars discussed using “he”, “him” and other male pronouns in English. I’m a woman who both creates and enjoys games. Makes me feel alone, but also happy that my native language has gender neutral pronouns.

caption: White neighbor, in conversation. I felt this person was implying that the black girl wasn’t qualified, or that she only got it out of affirmative action. Why not just say “I was fully qualified, but they gave the job to someone else”? I’m a person of color and I wonder if people think that about me. Made me sad.
quote: “I was fully qualified for the job, but they gave it to a black girl.”
actual_quote: I was fully qualified for the job, but they gave it to a black girl.

caption: Headmaster of the private school I attended on scholarship, while discussing university applications and my financial difficulties in paying tuition.Made me feel like I shouldn’t have dreams or aspirations, just because my family is poor. I was a straight A student and I graduated as top student in my class, but none of that counts when it comes to university.
quote: “My advice to you, stop wasting your time and look for a job that will pay the bills.”
actual_quote: My advice to you, stop wasting your time and look for a job that will pay the bills.

caption: My dad, when we were watching TV. Made me feel angry and sad that as an asexual girl, he probably won’t think I’m ‘normal’ for not being attracted to the 'opposite’ sex.
quote: “Of course I’m attracted to Pamela Anderson! What normal man wouldn’t be?”
actual_quote: Of course I’m attracted to Pamela Anderson! What normal man wouldn’t be?

caption: My coworker to me. 21 years old, in Florida. Made me angry, speechless.
quote: “You much more refined than other Black girls.”
actual_quote: You much more refined than other Black girls.

caption: Rest In Power | We are suspending Microaggressions today in memory of Troy Davis, who was killed last night by the state of Georgia despite substantial doubt about his conviction. Our blog is so limited by what we do not post; the larger markers of privilege and power that are structured into unjust institutions. Our posts cannot always encapsulate the scale of these injustices.
quote:
Rest In Power | We are suspending Microaggressions today in memory of Troy Davis, who was killed last night by the state of Georgia despite substantial doubt about his conviction. Our blog is so limited by what we do not post; the larger markers of privilege and power that are structured into unjust institutions. Our posts cannot always encapsulate the scale of these injustices.
We will continue the queue tomorrow. Please post in the comments your thoughts about the case and ways that other readers can be involved and organize around issues of legal justice. We include (updated) links below the jump.

caption: On my way into the mall, I passed by a couple of security guards talking amongst each other. One of them said, “Well, she had such a nice ass. How could I not whistle at her?” 15 years old, August, at a mall in Israel. Made me feel like I, as a woman, am just there for show.
quote: On my way into the mall, I passed by a couple of security guards talking amongst each other. One of them said, “Well, she had such a nice ass. How could I not whistle at her?” 15 years old, August, at a mall in Israel. Made me feel like I, as a woman, am just there for show.

caption: Random stranger referring to me pushing my wheelchair that I have used my entire life. Made me feel belittled. We don’t “congratulate people for walking well, so what did she even mean?
quote: “Wow, you are getting pretty good at that thing.”
actual_quote: Wow, you are getting pretty good at that thing.

caption: Whenever I am carrying large or bulky objects, I am always asked if I want help. My brother never is, despite the fact that he is a year younger and smaller than I am. Makes me feel belittled and put up on some sort of cushy pedestal.
quote: Whenever I am carrying large or bulky objects, I am always asked if I want help. My brother never is, despite the fact that he is a year younger and smaller than I am. Makes me feel belittled and put up on some sort of cushy pedestal.

caption: Said to me, an asexual woman, when I voiced frustration. Made me feel devalued and ridiculous.
quote: “You just need to get laid.”
actual_quote: You just need to get laid.

caption: Wearing a t-shirt like this.
While at work in a kitchen all the other employees started making Chewbacca noises. I mentioned that I could never make the noise properly.
quote:
While at work in a kitchen all the other employees started making Chewbacca noises. I mentioned that I could never make the noise properly.
One of my fellow employees said, “You have to use the back of your throat, I’m sure you have practice at that.” I asked him how he knew I had ever performed such an action and he responded with, “Every girl gives a blow job at least once.”

caption: I have Asperger’s Syndrome and my mother constantly tells me whenever we go somewhere that plans might change suddenly or something unexpected might happen and I need to be prepared for it so that I don’t have a melt down.
quote:
I have Asperger’s Syndrome and my mother constantly tells me whenever we go somewhere that plans might change suddenly or something unexpected might happen and I need to be prepared for it so that I don’t have a melt down.
If I could stop them from happening I would, they’re not fun for me either. I feel like I’m more misunderstood now than before I was diagnosed and I feel so isolated.

caption: The first sentence describing a local Groupon for makeup application. So now we are encouraging catcalls?
quote: “Like a donut, the face needs to be tastefully powdered so that it catches the eye of hungry construction workers. Don a deliciously dapper mug with today’s Groupon to Oasis Day Spa.”
actual_quote: Like a donut, the face needs to be tastefully powdered so that it catches the eye of hungry construction workers. Don a deliciously dapper mug with today’s Groupon to Oasis Day Spa.

caption: Comedian Dat Phan in a commercial for DirecTV.

A mother to her approximately 4 year-old son at the playground when he attempted to play with some other children who were speaking Spanish. As the parent of a biracial/bilingual child, this made me feel sad and angry.
quote: “You can’t play with them - they don’t speak English.”
actual_quote: You can’t play with them - they don’t speak English.

caption: After taking my male partner out for a nice dinner, I (female) ask the waiter for the check.  The waiter brings the check to the table and hands it to my partner. I hand back the check with my credit card, only to have the card and receipt handed back to my partner for a signature minutes later.
quote: After taking my male partner out for a nice dinner, I (female) ask the waiter for the check.  The waiter brings the check to the table and hands it to my partner. I hand back the check with my credit card, only to have the card and receipt handed back to my partner for a signature minutes later.

caption: When my husband and I were looking for our first apartment together, upon hearing my Indian name, the landlord asked our realtor if my cooking is going to stink up his hallways. Brooklyn, NY. I shrugged it off at the time - some people are jerks - but now it makes me furious.
quote: When my husband and I were looking for our first apartment together, upon hearing my Indian name, the landlord asked our realtor if my cooking is going to stink up his hallways. Brooklyn, NY. I shrugged it off at the time - some people are jerks - but now it makes me furious.

caption: To me, a black woman.
quote: “Why do you talk so white?”
actual_quote: Why do you talk so white?

caption: I’m a university instructor. The Strauss-Kahn affair came up in class, and its aftermath in French politics: lots of women in France are coming forward to denounce a sexist culture. I find myself worried about whether the men in the class (all white middle-class) will feel victimized. So I start qualifying everything I say, even about rape, with things like “Of course, men can be harrassed and raped too.” I was scared of being seen as a strident feminist, and I self-censored because I didn’t want the men in the class to feel challenged.
quote: I’m a university instructor. The Strauss-Kahn affair came up in class, and its aftermath in French politics: lots of women in France are coming forward to denounce a sexist culture. I find myself worried about whether the men in the class (all white middle-class) will feel victimized. So I start qualifying everything I say, even about rape, with things like “Of course, men can be harrassed and raped too.” I was scared of being seen as a strident feminist, and I self-censored because I didn’t want the men in the class to feel challenged.

caption: A college professor in a research-based course. I was too uncomfortable to speak up.
quote: “Surveying gender is easy because there’s only male and female.”
actual_quote: Surveying gender is easy because there’s only male and female.

caption: A couple of years ago, I worked briefly in retail. I would often come to work without make-up on, although I was told (informally) that it was part of the “uniform” of our all-female team of sales assistants. My boss would often reprimand me for it.
quote:
A couple of years ago, I worked briefly in retail. I would often come to work without make-up on, although I was told (informally) that it was part of the “uniform” of our all-female team of sales assistants. My boss would often reprimand me for it.
Once, in his most patronising tone, he said to me, “In this world, it’s so important that you look your best at all times.” I was furious, but I kept quiet. I’m a young woman. If I were male, he wouldn’t have said that.

caption: In the recent August issue of Shape magazine, there was an article called “America The Beautiful”, in which the writers “searched high and low for the most coveted looks across the country, then tapped the top experts in those cities for their get-gorgeous tips.”
quote:
In the recent August issue of Shape magazine, there was an article called “America The Beautiful”, in which the writers “searched high and low for the most coveted looks across the country, then tapped the top experts in those cities for their get-gorgeous tips.”
For Kansas City, KS, the most desirable trait is “a peaches ‘n’ cream complexion.” The writer goes on to say, “Porcelain white skin and naturally flushed cheeks come easily to these Midwestern women.” Apparently dark skinned women don’t exist in Kansas City.

caption: A Christian classmate, after telling her my religion. I was angry that my faith would change her opinion of me, frustrated that she would “forget” I wasn’t like her, like there was something wrong with me.
quote: “It’s okay. I won’t think of you as Jewish.”
actual_quote: It’s okay. I won’t think of you as Jewish.

caption: My parents and I overstayed our visa since I was five years old. Raised as an American, but at every step encountered roadblocks. It makes me feel like I am tourist, with no place to call home. I have no future here or in my country of birth. I am invisible in every way.
quote: “Sorry, you can’t do this trip with your high school friends… Sorry, you can’t qualify for scholarships… Sorry, you can’t work here… Sorry, you can’t open a bank account… Sorry, you can’t live here.”
actual_quote: Sorry, you can’t do this trip with your high school friends… Sorry, you can’t qualify for scholarships… Sorry, you can’t work here… Sorry, you can’t open a bank account… Sorry, you can’t live here.

caption: Question asked by a “friend” in high school to me, a bi-racial (half black/half white) teen.
quote: “Would it bother you if I called you nigger?”
actual_quote: Would it bother you if I called you nigger?

caption: I get this constantly from my mother about my butch presentation.
quote: “Why do you try to look so unfriendly instead of like a nice girl? You’ll never get a job when you look like white trash.”
actual_quote: Why do you try to look so unfriendly instead of like a nice girl? You’ll never get a job when you look like white trash.

caption: My friend’s mom, upon being introduced to me, a bisexual female. “Dave” is Daisy, my male to female transgendered ex-girlfriend. Made me feel insulted, as if people think the only way a trans person can have a relationship is with somebody who can’t do better. Saddened that this woman thought this was a compliment.
quote: “THAT’S her? She’s beautiful! When you said she dated Dave I assumed she’d be a beastly creature!”
actual_quote: THAT’S her? She’s beautiful! When you said she dated Dave I assumed she’d be a beastly creature!

caption: Said by my coworker, a white ciswoman, during happy hour at a bar after work. Made me feel trapped, like I couldn’t explain that gender does not equal sexuality without sounding like “the mean queer.”
quote: “Believe me, my son is NOT gay. He has never once touched a Barbie, he’s built like a linebacker, and he’s a real man’s man.”
actual_quote: Believe me, my son is NOT gay. He has never once touched a Barbie, he’s built like a linebacker, and he’s a real man’s man.

caption: In 9th grade, our “health” teacher sits us down and has us watch a video in which a speaker tells us about how selfish it is for rape victims to want abortions if they become pregnant.
quote: In 9th grade, our “health” teacher sits us down and has us watch a video in which a speaker tells us about how selfish it is for rape victims to want abortions if they become pregnant.

caption: Because I’m a 5’ 2" girl, I apparently cannot carry a box of groceries out to a customers car despite the fact that all I really have to do is , push the car out to the parking lot and lift the box into the vehicle. This said after I had already placed the box in the cart.
quote: “No, can you get one of the boys to carry that out? It’s too heavy for you.”
actual_quote: No, can you get one of the boys to carry that out? It’s too heavy for you.

caption: Said to me (a queer female who has been diagnosed with Asperger’s) by my partner (an “open-minded” woman who works at a non-profit in which she works with adolescents with special needs.) This was supposed to be a “joke”. I felt not amused, threatened, misunderstood, stigmatized, minimized.
quote: “Wait, can I catch your Asperger’s?”
actual_quote: Wait, can I catch your Asperger’s?

caption: I’m a 29 year-old second-generation Indian American woman born in San Diego. A young coworker asks me this, after asking about the festival Holi. He’s a very nice young white man with a genuine curiosity about other cultures, so all I can muster is a “… no…” and a change of subject.But I wanted to say to him “My priest said you guys, like, worship torture, is that true?” I felt scared and bewildered, not at him but at his church’s depiction of my faith and culture as some sort of Legion of Doom.
quote: “My pastor said you guys, like, worship the darkness. Is that true?”
actual_quote: My pastor said you guys, like, worship the darkness. Is that true?

caption: One of the bullet points in my sister’s 7th grade Sex Ed packet: “Students will be taught the benefits of a monogamous, heterosexual marriage.” Arizona, 2010. Made me feel annoyed, disappointed.
quote: One of the bullet points in my sister’s 7th grade Sex Ed packet: “Students will be taught the benefits of a monogamous, heterosexual marriage.” Arizona, 2010. Made me feel annoyed, disappointed.

caption: I was 17, in high school; said to me by my white peers while speaking to a Mexican friend. I’m Mexican-Dominican.It made me feel like I wasn’t “enough” of my own ethnicity to speak my native language, alienated, defensive.
quote: “You’re too white-washed to speak Spanish. Stop it.”
actual_quote: You’re too white-washed to speak Spanish. Stop it.

caption: At an electrical engineering class of all guys.
quote: “Anyone who can get a girl to enroll in this class gets extra credit.”
actual_quote: Anyone who can get a girl to enroll in this class gets extra credit.

caption: My featured headlines on my Yahoo News feed change when I log into a profile that specifies that I am female. Usually, they change from world events-heavy to stories about celebrity breakups and miracle diets. Makes me feel pigeonholed, stereotyped and dismissed as frivolous.
quote: My featured headlines on my Yahoo News feed change when I log into a profile that specifies that I am female. Usually, they change from world events-heavy to stories about celebrity breakups and miracle diets. Makes me feel pigeonholed, stereotyped and dismissed as frivolous.

caption: One of two people talking about me. I was hugely disappointed because I had plenty of respect for her.
quote: “She’s pretty for a Black girl.”
actual_quote: She’s pretty for a Black girl.

caption: My brother presenting his theory that I’m not actually bisexual. I’m only 17, and figuring out my sexuality isn’t easy.  Made me feel like I’m making my sexuality up for attention, like I’m trying to be something that doesn’t exist, or that exists, but I’m not qualified for.
quote: “I’ll believe it when you don’t just hook up with girls, but actually bring one home as your girlfriend.”
actual_quote: I’ll believe it when you don’t just hook up with girls, but actually bring one home as your girlfriend.

caption: My uncle asks what I’m studying. Feminist Methodology. He says you don’t need to read anymore, that’s just milking men for all their worth.
quote:
My uncle asks what I’m studying. Feminist Methodology. He says you don’t need to read anymore, that’s just milking men for all their worth.
19, in my home, 2011.  Made me feel misunderstood, frustrated
“You look so pretty washing the dishes! I’m glad you’re learning young. That way, when you get married, you’ll know what to do.”
actual_quote: You look so pretty washing the dishes! I’m glad you’re learning young. That way, when you get married, you’ll know what to do.

caption: Every time a character in a book is introduced in a way that focuses on how fat they are in a way to foreshadow laziness, cowardice, haughtiness, or other undesirable traits the character will exhibit later on.
quote:
Every time a character in a book is introduced in a way that focuses on how fat they are in a way to foreshadow laziness, cowardice, haughtiness, or other undesirable traits the character will exhibit later on.
Even J.K. Rowling, who tries to embed tolerance into her books, is guilty of doing this repeatedly. We meet a character, he or she is described as portley or corpulent, and later their habitual laziness or cowardice is linked to their fatness.

caption: I am an overweight half Chinese and half white female. I’m trying to get in shape because I feel better and more energized when I’m active. Looking better in clothes is a nice bonus.
quote:
I am an overweight half Chinese and half white female. I’m trying to get in shape because I feel better and more energized when I’m active. Looking better in clothes is a nice bonus.
My Chinese mom’s response to my body being more tight after a month of consistent exercise: “Great, now lose more. You’re starting to look more Asian, isn’t that great?”
I’m 27 years old, facing my mom’s new-found need for me to be pretty (thin) enough to snag someone to fertilize my eggs and give her grandbabies. I felt like my cultural heritage can only exist in relation to my size and weight. And like, somehow, even though my white dad was good enough for her, my being their child isn’t.

caption: While working in a mail room, my coworkers and I are joking around. Someone makes a comment about how strange it is when people just smile all the time, or are walking around smiling at the sidewalk for no reason. I join in, saying, “Yeah, I only do that when I get laid.” Everyone laughs, but one jerk in the back starts making retching noises and continues doing so for at least one minute, adding, “eeew, images, urrggh”.
quote:
While working in a mail room, my coworkers and I are joking around. Someone makes a comment about how strange it is when people just smile all the time, or are walking around smiling at the sidewalk for no reason. I join in, saying, “Yeah, I only do that when I get laid.” Everyone laughs, but one jerk in the back starts making retching noises and continues doing so for at least one minute, adding, “eeew, images, urrggh”.
I am a young, fat, white cis-female at college in WI. Made me feel enraged, desexualized, marginalized, and body disphoric.
“Hey, if you don’t like it when they use ‘gay’ like that, then don’t pay attention to them. Don’t let yourself get so worked up about it.”
actual_quote: Hey, if you don’t like it when they use ‘gay’ like that, then don’t pay attention to them. Don’t let yourself get so worked up about it.

caption: An older man who I am hoping is a veteran feels the need to tell me, “I killed many of your people, but I have no ill feelings towards the Vietnamese.” I’m Filipino.
quote: An older man who I am hoping is a veteran feels the need to tell me, “I killed many of your people, but I have no ill feelings towards the Vietnamese.” I’m Filipino.

caption: Mother to me. 19 years old, Singapore. Made me angry, ashamed, feel stripped of autonomy.
quote: “You’re asking for trouble with those jeans.”
actual_quote: You’re asking for trouble with those jeans.

caption: People still express polite surprise after finding out that I’m still bisexual, even after college. It makes me feel like my sexuality is invalid to them.
quote: People still express polite surprise after finding out that I’m still bisexual, even after college. It makes me feel like my sexuality is invalid to them.
“You aren’t really disabled.”
actual_quote: You aren’t really disabled.

caption: After my paternal cousin had her first daughter, her father and stepmother, both white, announced to the family that they were going by “Lolo” and “Lola”, because they knew my sister and I used those terms to refer to our Filipino maternal grandparents. Made me feel annoyed that although they had no direct ties to anyone Filipino and the grandchild was white on both sides, they still appropriated the terms because they thought it was “cute”.
quote: After my paternal cousin had her first daughter, her father and stepmother, both white, announced to the family that they were going by “Lolo” and “Lola”, because they knew my sister and I used those terms to refer to our Filipino maternal grandparents. Made me feel annoyed that although they had no direct ties to anyone Filipino and the grandchild was white on both sides, they still appropriated the terms because they thought it was “cute”.

caption: I’m mixed race but look white. My first name is Native American and many black/African Americans have my last name. When meeting my friend’s mother, who is white and upper-middle class, she said “Oh! I thought you would be black. Your name sounds ETHNIC.”
quote:
I’m mixed race but look white. My first name is Native American and many black/African Americans have my last name. When meeting my friend’s mother, who is white and upper-middle class, she said “Oh! I thought you would be black. Your name sounds ETHNIC.”
Why would she think that it would be okay to say that? No matter what ethnic group/race one belongs to, that is a very rude statement.
In Alaska, friend's house; I was offended, shocked.

caption: My friend in my car while we are driving. I am Mexican American.
quote: ““You guys are really good gardeners”.”
actual_quote: “You guys are really good gardeners”.

caption: During my vacation to Mexico, I upload some pictures online for friends to see of my relatives. On one of the pictures, my friend comments: “Wow! Your cousins are dressed normal!” When I get back she tells me, “I didn’t know they had cars in Mexico”. I’m an 18 year-old Mexican American female. Made me feel offended, shocked, belittled, angry and worthless.
quote: During my vacation to Mexico, I upload some pictures online for friends to see of my relatives. On one of the pictures, my friend comments: “Wow! Your cousins are dressed normal!” When I get back she tells me, “I didn’t know they had cars in Mexico”. I’m an 18 year-old Mexican American female. Made me feel offended, shocked, belittled, angry and worthless.

caption: On the show Toddlers & Tiaras, a mother was talking about her little girl who is a tomboy. She likes to hunt with her father and loves playing soccer. The mother concludes that the little girl is “part girl, part boy.” Apparently, liking soccer and hunting makes you a boy.
quote: On the show Toddlers & Tiaras, a mother was talking about her little girl who is a tomboy. She likes to hunt with her father and loves playing soccer. The mother concludes that the little girl is “part girl, part boy.” Apparently, liking soccer and hunting makes you a boy.

caption: I am carrying a little cousin when an uncle sees me and says, “Good, that way you’ll practice for when you have kids.” I tell him, “I don’t want any kids.” He just looks at me in irritated disbelief and says, “Yes, you will.” He shakes his head dismissively before leaving.
quote: I am carrying a little cousin when an uncle sees me and says, “Good, that way you’ll practice for when you have kids.” I tell him, “I don’t want any kids.” He just looks at me in irritated disbelief and says, “Yes, you will.” He shakes his head dismissively before leaving.

caption: 18 year-old college student who has been homeless several times with my “normal” parents. I pass as middle class. Made me feel unable to talk about my past.
quote: “I’m fine with homeless people who have psychological disorders, but what I don’t understand is NORMAL people who have to be homeless. Why don’t they get jobs? Why don’t they get help from family?”
actual_quote: I’m fine with homeless people who have psychological disorders, but what I don’t understand is NORMAL people who have to be homeless. Why don’t they get jobs? Why don’t they get help from family?

caption: While the girls in my gym class start to play ultimate, all the boys are lined up on one side of the field, ready to split into teams for football. I walk over to join that line and they refuse to make space for me. One of them tells me to go play frisbee with the girls. Both the male gym teacher and my group of male friends just stand there and stare at me. Five years ago in my grade 10 gym class. I felt unwanted, incapable, some how less than everyone else.
quote: While the girls in my gym class start to play ultimate, all the boys are lined up on one side of the field, ready to split into teams for football. I walk over to join that line and they refuse to make space for me. One of them tells me to go play frisbee with the girls. Both the male gym teacher and my group of male friends just stand there and stare at me. Five years ago in my grade 10 gym class. I felt unwanted, incapable, some how less than everyone else.

caption: A middle-aged woman walks in the Japanese restaurant I work at and asks me if we have Kikkoman brand soy sauce.  I tell her that we don’t have that brand and she looks at me, frustrated, and says, “I don’t think Orientals work here. Orientals would know the difference.”
quote: A middle-aged woman walks in the Japanese restaurant I work at and asks me if we have Kikkoman brand soy sauce.  I tell her that we don’t have that brand and she looks at me, frustrated, and says, “I don’t think Orientals work here. Orientals would know the difference.”

caption: My mothers’ opinion on gender stereotypes.
quote: “We all fall into those roles eventually.”
actual_quote: We all fall into those roles eventually.

caption: I’m walking home with my boyfriend after a date. We’d both dressed up for the date; I’m wearing a strapless, body-hugging mini-dress.
quote:
I’m walking home with my boyfriend after a date. We’d both dressed up for the date; I’m wearing a strapless, body-hugging mini-dress.
A man yells, almost in an angry and malicious tone, “NICE DRESS!” as his car drives by. I then found myself having to explain to my boyfriend why, even though the man didn’t literally say anything bad, I am offended by his unsolicited remark.
Made me angry with the random man; exasperated with boyfriend; frustrated that some stranger decided to ruin my date; self-loathing for letting a stranger ruin my date.

caption: What he said when I told him to wear a condom because I wasn’t on birth control, in an otherwise frank and equitable discussion about our sexual preferences. Clearly his pleasure was more important than not getting me pregnant.
quote: “Wow, that’s really irresponsible of you.”
actual_quote: Wow, that’s really irresponsible of you.

caption: Made me feel attacked, forced to defend myself; like the speaker thought I was defective for not fitting his stereotypes.
quote: “How does A WOMAN get the idea to study computer science?”
actual_quote: How does A WOMAN get the idea to study computer science?

caption: When I was over at my friend’s house, her mother called my friend out of the room for a chat. When my friend returned, she asked my girlfriend and I to not sit next to each other because it made her mother uncomfortable, and then returned to cuddling in her boyfriend’s lap
quote:
When I was over at my friend’s house, her mother called my friend out of the room for a chat. When my friend returned, she asked my girlfriend and I to not sit next to each other because it made her mother uncomfortable, and then returned to cuddling in her boyfriend’s lap
An entire room of people I considered close friends heard her say this and no one said a word. I made a half-hearted attempt to say, “but that’s ridiculous,” and still everyone stared silently at the floor.

caption: This boy said this after spilling a drink all over his new suede shoes.
quote: “Wow, I’m so autistic.”
actual_quote: Wow, I’m so autistic.

caption: Two business-end people in the office across from me. I’m a trans woman, and have been out at the lab for four months now.
quote: “Gender and birth date are two fields that will never change.”
actual_quote: Gender and birth date are two fields that will never change.

caption: I was talking about how biased the SAT is for low income students who can’t afford SAT prep. A friend (who goes to a prestigious university) said, “Well, those kids probably can’t afford these great schools anyway.” I couldn’t afford SAT prep and go to an expensive, private university on scholarships, grants and federal aid.
quote: I was talking about how biased the SAT is for low income students who can’t afford SAT prep. A friend (who goes to a prestigious university) said, “Well, those kids probably can’t afford these great schools anyway.” I couldn’t afford SAT prep and go to an expensive, private university on scholarships, grants and federal aid.

caption: Frizz-Ease commercial on TV fairly often. Thank you for reminding me, an African American woman, once again that my hair is a birth defect that needs to be corrected.
quote: “What can you do with curly, frizzy hair? make it go away!”
actual_quote: What can you do with curly, frizzy hair? make it go away!

caption: Every time I disagree with my boyfriend’s father’s or step-mother’s political sentiments. Apparently, because I’m have bi-polar disorder, expressing an opinion or disagreeing with them is a symptom of mental illness and therefore should be disregarded.
quote: “Don’t get all manic on me now.”
actual_quote: Don’t get all manic on me now.

caption: Every time anyone asks “Are you a boy or a girl?” I don’t know how to respond because I’m genderqueer and apparently my identity doesn’t exist. Everywhere, all the time. Makes me feel invisible, othered, unrecognized.
quote: Every time anyone asks “Are you a boy or a girl?” I don’t know how to respond because I’m genderqueer and apparently my identity doesn’t exist. Everywhere, all the time. Makes me feel invisible, othered, unrecognized.

caption: Every time I see a commercial for Carl’s Jr. (aka Hardees), usually featuring models in swimsuits or men doing ‘men’ things. Makes me feel like I’m not welcome in Carl’s Jr. Since when are fast food restaurants supposed to be for only 50% of the population?
quote: Every time I see a commercial for Carl’s Jr. (aka Hardees), usually featuring models in swimsuits or men doing ‘men’ things. Makes me feel like I’m not welcome in Carl’s Jr. Since when are fast food restaurants supposed to be for only 50% of the population?

caption: When I tell people that I have bipolar disorder. Makes me feel invalidated, irritated, tired.
quote: “You look normal.”
actual_quote: You look normal.

caption: Guy says this to me on one of the hottest days of the year. I am of Indian descent, but was born in the Northeast of the US. July, at a meeting. It made me feel like though I am American, I’m not considered as such.
quote: “Well, you must like this weather, right?”
actual_quote: Well, you must like this weather, right?

caption: White Hispanic girl named Alexis from my high school. I understood that it was innocent ignorance on her part, but being black myself, I did wonder if she associated me with being ghetto, despite us both going to an upper-middle class private high school.
quote: “There’s a black doll at the Dollar Store named Alexis; It’s like a ghetto mini me!”
actual_quote: There’s a black doll at the Dollar Store named Alexis; It’s like a ghetto mini me!

caption: My college, which is a minority majority college, just hired five new vice presidents. One is a person of color, and all of them are male, even though I know their hiring pool was much more diverse. Made me feel underrepresented and betrayed by a college that supposedly values social justice.
quote: My college, which is a minority majority college, just hired five new vice presidents. One is a person of color, and all of them are male, even though I know their hiring pool was much more diverse. Made me feel underrepresented and betrayed by a college that supposedly values social justice.

caption: A little girl that my daughter befriended at the library kept asking over and over.My daughter is 2 years old and was wearing a red shirt, jeans shorts, and blue shoes (an outfit she chose herself). Sad that I have to constantly defend my daughters choice to define her gender however she wants.
quote: “Why doesn’t she look like a girl? She looks like a boy.”
actual_quote: Why doesn’t she look like a girl? She looks like a boy.

caption: My dad, after I walked in the room with my hair up. One of the many comments on how he thinks the girls in my family should act.I felt angry that he would be disappointed in me if I didn’t fit into a certain gender stereotype. Made me realize that parents aren’t always right, and for that, I was relieved.
quote: “Did you cut your hair? We don’t like short hair on our girls in this family.”
actual_quote: Did you cut your hair? We don’t like short hair on our girls in this family.

caption: I’m filling out a personality test form and it asks whether I find men or women attractive.
quote:
I’m filling out a personality test form and it asks whether I find men or women attractive.
I’m a 21 year old, genderqueer “bi"sexual.  Made me feel annoyed about the gender binary presented and like my sexuality is invisible

caption: My boyfriend’s dad, talking about my job unloading boxes at a large retailer. July 2011. Made me dread all the conversations like this I’ll have to have in the coming years. Made me feel inadequate.
quote: “You know, if I were hiring for a job like that, I don’t know that I would hire, you know, a young lady.”
actual_quote: You know, if I were hiring for a job like that, I don’t know that I would hire, you know, a young lady.

caption: #reasonstobeatyourgirlfriend is trending on Twitter
quote:
#reasonstobeatyourgirlfriend is trending on Twitter
31st July 2011, makes me feel depressed

caption: I’m coordinating a project, and a director wants to give my name to her staff to send me submissions. With her pen poised, she asks “So who do they send things to?” I say my name, and she replies exasperated and throws her pen down “Oh, that’s much too long and complicated, why don’t you just email me.”
quote:
I’m coordinating a project, and a director wants to give my name to her staff to send me submissions. With her pen poised, she asks “So who do they send things to?” I say my name, and she replies exasperated and throws her pen down “Oh, that’s much too long and complicated, why don’t you just email me.”
I just looked at her and spelled it out. I am 31, June 2011, Toronto. Made me feel irritated because I wanted to respond and say, “What? my non-white, hyphenated name, is too complicated for you?”

caption: My professor wrote this on my evaluation sheet for a project I did on game theory and video game players.
quote: “I didn’t know girls played video games.”
actual_quote: I didn’t know girls played video games.

caption: Asked to me by a man in a neighbourhood café. I have lived in Norway my entire life. I am multiracial. It made me feel insulted, sad, like I am not allowed to belong anywhere.
quote: “Do you speak Norwegian?”
actual_quote: Do you speak Norwegian?

caption: My facebook newsfeed today.
quote: “Asian toddlers are the cutest things in the woorld. Adopting a few on eBay. No… but seriously.”
actual_quote: Asian toddlers are the cutest things in the woorld. Adopting a few on eBay. No… but seriously.

caption: College frat boy to me, a Pakistani-American 19-year-old. I didn’t want to clarify that there’s a difference between Pakistani and Indian. Or that we’re not all represented by Western media’s interpretation with accents, mustaches,  and 7-11s. At a college party at a Liberal Arts Hippie School, in a large crowd. Made me feel like I was a fetish, a type of woman that he’d like to check off on a list.
quote: “Oh, I watch that show Outsourced! JAI HO!!”
actual_quote: Oh, I watch that show Outsourced! JAI HO!!

caption: My fifth grade teacher, after mentioning that I was Arabic. Made me feel generalized and overlooked.
quote: “No, I can tell you aren’t. You have lighter skin so it’s impossible.”
actual_quote: No, I can tell you aren’t. You have lighter skin so it’s impossible.

caption: On my way to the bus stop, I witnessed an argument escalating between a young man and a young woman. She was becoming violent, and he threatened her verbally. It seemed unsafe for me to ask what was going on, so I called the police to report what was going on. The 911 operator asked me if either of the parties involved was black.
quote: On my way to the bus stop, I witnessed an argument escalating between a young man and a young woman. She was becoming violent, and he threatened her verbally. It seemed unsafe for me to ask what was going on, so I called the police to report what was going on. The 911 operator asked me if either of the parties involved was black.

caption: Every time I mention my country or my race. Thank you for saying that my race and/or my nationality makes me beautiful… but I just want to be seen as a person, not a fetish.
quote: “People of mixed-race are so beautiful! Puerto Rico has the most beautiful women!”
actual_quote: People of mixed-race are so beautiful! Puerto Rico has the most beautiful women!

caption: Two of my friends (both 19-yr-old college students) reacting to bisexuality.
quote: “Being bi is just a transition step between straight and gay. People who are bi just need to choose!”
actual_quote: Being bi is just a transition step between straight and gay. People who are bi just need to choose!

caption: Girl from Arizona to me on a New York rooftop.
quote: “I was kidding. I know you’re Puerto Rican, not Mexican. And I think that’s pretty sexy.”
actual_quote: I was kidding. I know you’re Puerto Rican, not Mexican. And I think that’s pretty sexy.

caption: While attending a charity boxing match between Marines and Firefighters/PD, there was ONE match where women were boxing. There was a firefighter boxing a policewoman. During the match, the announcer kept referring to them as “somebody’s mom” and said, “I’d hate to get a spanking from one of these moms."  In order to get the crowd going, he said, "Wouldn’t you cheer if that was your mom in there?” At no time during the men’s matches were their children or status as a parent mentioned. Even though the women were included, they were still being judged by how they are in relationship to another person, as if they were not people of themselves on their own merit.
quote: While attending a charity boxing match between Marines and Firefighters/PD, there was ONE match where women were boxing. There was a firefighter boxing a policewoman. During the match, the announcer kept referring to them as “somebody’s mom” and said, “I’d hate to get a spanking from one of these moms."  In order to get the crowd going, he said, "Wouldn’t you cheer if that was your mom in there?” At no time during the men’s matches were their children or status as a parent mentioned. Even though the women were included, they were still being judged by how they are in relationship to another person, as if they were not people of themselves on their own merit.

caption: A woman at my church - one that supposedly is welcoming to gender and sexual minorities. Completely worthless, completely erased. Trans men don’t always start out looking masculine.
quote: “But you’re so cute! Why do you want to be a boy?”
actual_quote: But you’re so cute! Why do you want to be a boy?

quote: “I’m male, and am asking this question to non-binary identified people. Why do you give so much of a crap? Why can’t you just lighten up, let the thread happen, and ignore it?”
actual_quote: I’m male, and am asking this question to non-binary identified people. Why do you give so much of a crap? Why can’t you just lighten up, let the thread happen, and ignore it?

caption: A multiple choice question asked me who brought agriculture, architecture, and Christianity to the Southwest. All the options were Spanish explorers and missionaries. This completely negates the substantial agricultural and architectural contributions of Native Americans. My mandatory summer history packet.
quote: A multiple choice question asked me who brought agriculture, architecture, and Christianity to the Southwest. All the options were Spanish explorers and missionaries. This completely negates the substantial agricultural and architectural contributions of Native Americans. My mandatory summer history packet.

caption: I opened my mouth for a strep test. I didn’t gag. The doctor said, “Oh! Your husband must LOVE you!” Then I gagged. “Oh, maybe not,” he said. I’m 23, 2011, Minnesota, urgent care. Made me feel ashamed, angry, disgusted.
quote: I opened my mouth for a strep test. I didn’t gag. The doctor said, “Oh! Your husband must LOVE you!” Then I gagged. “Oh, maybe not,” he said. I’m 23, 2011, Minnesota, urgent care. Made me feel ashamed, angry, disgusted.

caption: A woman on the bus is convinced that two of her Hispanic coworkers must being sleeping with the boss, because there is no reason they should make as much money as she, a white women, does.
quote: A woman on the bus is convinced that two of her Hispanic coworkers must being sleeping with the boss, because there is no reason they should make as much money as she, a white women, does.

caption: Another mom, someone I had never met before, at a backyard birthday party which my kindergarten-age daughter attended. Eventually she made it clear she meant ethnicity: “Are you …European?” I have an Eastern European parent and a First Nations (indigenous Canadian) parent and am Canadian-born and raised. I told her that. “Oh, I knew you were *something.*"  Her next question: "Do you work?” Uh, yeah, I own a business, thanks. I’m a middle aged mom in a suburb of Toronto. Made me momentarily confused. Isn’t it clear I’m another parent at the birthday party? What else could she mean? OH. I get it. Sigh.
quote: “What ARE you?”
actual_quote: What ARE you?

caption: I went to the doctor for unexplained severe headaches. The doctor asked about my sex life, asking if my boyfriend and I are using protection, etc. When I told him I had a very active sex life with my girlfriend at the time, he immediately told me he wanted to test me for HIV. This was never even a thought until I told him I was gay.
quote: I went to the doctor for unexplained severe headaches. The doctor asked about my sex life, asking if my boyfriend and I are using protection, etc. When I told him I had a very active sex life with my girlfriend at the time, he immediately told me he wanted to test me for HIV. This was never even a thought until I told him I was gay.

caption: On joining pickup soccer games (an almost exclusively male space), as a young looking 24 year old girl I either get overly-complimented or overly-patronized.
quote:
On joining pickup soccer games (an almost exclusively male space), as a young looking 24 year old girl I either get overly-complimented or overly-patronized.
“You must be tired… how are you keeping up?” “Wow, everyone underestimated you!” “You’re better than some of the guys here!"
It makes me feel like I’m hitting a ‘limit’ of what I’m allowed to do within my gender.

caption: My mother, when I came out to her as a trans man.
quote: “I still love you and accept that you were born this way, but you got it from your dad. His side of the family has the queer genes.”
actual_quote: I still love you and accept that you were born this way, but you got it from your dad. His side of the family has the queer genes.

caption: My brother, straight, 20’s, about the upside of his plane being delayed. Doesn’t know I’m a lesbian. Made me feel like my sexuality was a spectacle for other people to enjoy.
quote: “…but there was a lesbian couple in line who were saying a really passionate goodbye for like, half an hour, so I didn’t mind the wait.”
actual_quote: …but there was a lesbian couple in line who were saying a really passionate goodbye for like, half an hour, so I didn’t mind the wait.

caption: Every single time I am standing in a line, people use the space in front of me, no matter how small, to cut through. I am a female and short in stature. If it only happened sometimes, I’d shrug it off as coincidence. But as it is, it makes me feel invisible, like my presence doesn’t count.
quote: Every single time I am standing in a line, people use the space in front of me, no matter how small, to cut through. I am a female and short in stature. If it only happened sometimes, I’d shrug it off as coincidence. But as it is, it makes me feel invisible, like my presence doesn’t count.

caption: An 11 year old girl to me. When I tell her that’s not true, she says, “Well, that’s what I’ve heard.”
quote: “Indians (meaning First Nations) are paid $400 a month to sit on the couch and do nothing.”
actual_quote: Indians (meaning First Nations) are paid $400 a month to sit on the couch and do nothing.

caption: It’s that moment when I’m out with my son, whether with my fiance (his father) or not, and a person will walk past us, smile at my son, then immediately look at my bare finger, then up to my eyes, and look disapprovingly away. Like I’m no good as a mom because I’m not married with a huge diamond on my finger. Makes me feel self-conscious, judged, stereotyped.
quote: It’s that moment when I’m out with my son, whether with my fiance (his father) or not, and a person will walk past us, smile at my son, then immediately look at my bare finger, then up to my eyes, and look disapprovingly away. Like I’m no good as a mom because I’m not married with a huge diamond on my finger. Makes me feel self-conscious, judged, stereotyped.

caption: My mom, in response to my rant about my day where a bicyclist made kissing noises to me while riding by, the UPS man called me “sexy” three times in one sentence (can I just sign for the packages?), and while stuck in traffic another driver decided it would be a good idea to shout how hot I was and would I “have his babies.”
quote: “Well, what were you wearing?”
actual_quote: Well, what were you wearing?

caption: When sitting with some friends, they told some racist jokes. I said it was in bad taste, and they respond saying “It’s not like there are any ‘real’ ethnics around” when they are aware I’m a first generation American from Central America. I said “I’m here”, and they respond saying “You’re too 'white’ to be 'ethnic,’” referring to my light skin.
quote:
When sitting with some friends, they told some racist jokes. I said it was in bad taste, and they respond saying “It’s not like there are any ‘real’ ethnics around” when they are aware I’m a first generation American from Central America. I said “I’m here”, and they respond saying “You’re too 'white’ to be 'ethnic,’” referring to my light skin.
I am 20, USA, at a prestigious university. It made me feel trivialized, like I didn’t matter to the Hispanic community because of my skin tone.

caption: A text from a couple after they uninvited me from a Shabbos meal at the last minute. Living in Israel alone, I often have to rely on strangers for these meals. They are the first hosts, Orthodox or not, that have reacted with such bigotry. I am a 29 year old Jewish woman who is married to a woman back in the States.
quote: “We’re very sorry if we offended you. This was very uncomfortable for us.
